What do we have in Another? Leads in their early teens, small remote village, a mysterious curse caused by even more mysterious death; seemingly a perfect combination for a horror anime. Nothing can go wrong, right? Well, unless you overcomplicated stuff for no reason, make ridiculous and predictable deaths and in the end solve and explain nothing, it should work out right. I just wish someone told this to the staff.
Story: 6/10
A boy, Sakakibara Kouichi, comes into Hinamizawa… *cough* no… wait.. Yomiyama for the first time and right away he is greeted by a very mysterious group of his classmates, acting as if they werehiding a dead body in a closet, with one of them asking if he hadn’t been there before.  Of course he didn’t… or did he? As if it wasn’t enough, on his first school day he meets a girl that is seemingly ignored by everyone… or is she unseen? He then learns about a curse that causes a mysterious and improbable (read: ridiculous) death every month and repeats every year. This is because there is one person in the class that shouldn’t be there and is already dead (memories of the said person and everyone around are modified so no one knows anything).  

While this show had a LOT of promise and I genuinely loved it first few episodes, the plot slowly succumbed into a blood bath… by the end quite literally. Everything got messed up, the curse or how it started never got properly explained or, heaven forbid, permanently stopped, a certain character that could have ended it all within an episode pretended they knew nothing and let everyone die simply because. This is a perfect example of how NOT to do a mystery horror. One of the good points was that from the very beginning we were given hints about the dead person over and over.


Art: 8/10

There was very little wrong with the art or design. It was interesting, it was fluent, maybe slightly unfitting for this kind of anime but that’s about it.


Sound: 7/10

Opening was very good, although some people complain about it. Sound itself in anime managed to bring the atmosphere but it wasn’t anything worth listening to on its own.


Characters: 5/10

This is the second thing this anime could have done perfectly, yet it showed us how perfectly they could mess it up. Kouichi is a very good character, slightly boring but realistic. Misaki Mei turns from a mysterious plot drive to a moe fanservice into a spineless idiot (that is, of course, never addressed within the series). The rest of the cast is there just for filling empty space, no one really memorable or extremely well done and definitely no one with a character development (turning into an insane murderer doesn’t count). Actually, at the end even Kouichi acts as if nothing happened so I’m not even sure if there is ANY character development at all.


Enjoyment: 5/10

As much as I loved the plot and characters at the beginning I hated them at the end. Many character made unreasonable decisions that were only explained by “it’s the curse” including the leads. Charm of moe characters escapes me, so the fanservice was a waste of time for me. But it still had a very good start so it wasn’t completely horrible.


Overall: 6/10

This is a perfect example of series that gradually get worse and manage to completely float away from its genre. During the last few episodes, the only mystery there is, is that you didn’t know how people are going to die until about 3 minutes before their death. The curse was turned into a villainous deus ex machina that could control people’s mind. No kidding. Not to mention that the end is as conclusive as would packing stuff and running away be (if the curse doesn’t catch you, of course).

Horror is a genre that tends to be rare in anime. What horror animes exist tend to be of high quality, but generally, pure horror fiction is a woefully unrepresented genre in anime. Thankfully, after finishing Another, I am proud to say that the anime horror genre has found itself another gem.
Another concerns a young student named Sakakibara Kouichi who moves to a rural town and transfers into the local school's third class. He finds himself drawn in by the mystery of a strange girl named Misaki who wears an eyepatch and acts extremely distant. Kouichi soon finds himself in a whirlwind of supernatural intrigueand terror. Beyond this, I don't believe any more of the plot should be given away. I feel that Another works best as a story that you go into knowing as little as possible.


Another is, for the most part, a tightly written horror story. Admittedly, the first episode or two is slow and at first glance the story sounds like the same old ghost story that has been beaten to death in countless horror movies. However, the story quickly takes off and becomes extremely unpredictable, creating a wildly unique story that stands out from the often formulaic horror genre. The pacing of the series is simply excellent. The early parts of the series settle for a surreal and unsettling atmosphere, whereas the plot starts to accelerate in the latter part until it reaches a chaotic frenzy in its conclusion.


Another works extremely well at establishing tension and a growing sense of dread. Bizarre dream sequences, startling imagery, and gory deaths that would make Higurashi proud all work together to create an intense viewing experience. Additionally, Another devotes almost all of its time and energy to developing a rich story and is largely free of filler and pandering, save for a beach episode.


Naturally, the series is not without a few flaws. Another sports a large cast of characters but only a few of them are gifted with much in the way of character development. This isn't a large issue, but I was left wanting to know more about several of the characters. Additionally, as with many supernatural mysteries, there are gaps in logic present in the story. It doesn't require as much suspension of disbelief as say, Mirai Nikki, but those who are bothered by such things are warned.


The animation quality is excellent. Although you wouldn't imagine a show of Another's profile to receive a top quality animation job, P.A. Works has created a surprisingly good looking show. Characters are consistently sharply drawn and the backgrounds are lush with detail. The show's few action sequences are fluidly animated. The dark artistic imagery, such as the show's fixation upon dolls, fits the eerie tone well.


Horror is many times defined by its soundtrack, a test that Another passes with flying colors. Dark moody pieces set the tone for many a scene and frenzied music punctuates the more shocking moments in the story. The opening theme is decent, whereas the ending theme is forgettable. There are few complaints to be found with the voice cast, as all the performers deliver commendable performances.


Another is a fantastic example of horror done right in an anime. Its not “scary” per say, but the atmosphere will be eaten up by horror and mystery fans alike. Attractive animation, solid pacing, and a compelling mystery all make Another a must-see for long-time horror fans or for those who are looking to get into the genre.

I was amazed at how great Another was. I must say that there were lots of things that had really stood out to me while I was watching. The most noticeable thing for me was the art and sound. In my opinion the art and sound really enhanced the atmosphere of the story and the events that were taking place. There are lots of shows with the similar "main character moves to newplace" "strange things happen" "people die" type plot however out of the many that I have seen Another's unique take on this was very enticing... exciting. "Another" thing (get it?) I loved most about Another was that it brought to me the lovable and memorable character Mei Misaki. There are in the anime-verse millions, of mysterious girls characters, Mei Misaki is perhaps my number one favorite for now. I'll say this now... if you have problems of dolls, lots of blood, and unexpected death, I would probably not watch the first episode or any episode. 
Plot/Setting:
I'm not going to lie, I was very confused on what the heck was happening at first. It's like a mix of Series of Unfortunate Events, Clue, The Final Destination, and Stephen King's The Shining. For twelve episodes, a lot happens. You cannot miss a second of this or you'll be lost out of your mind. However, this anime, because it is in the horror genre, was able to grab me right way. I was hook like afish out of water! I couldn't stop watching it and watching it! It's a very mysterious, horrific plot line, and for something that is based off a Japanese Book, it's very well done. Yes, it's based off a book not a manga. Now...I would love to pick up the book, and if I could speak Japanese, I would. 


The setting really made me a bit...mad until I understood why there was so much rain. I'll tell you right now, and here's a geography lesson for you all, it does not rain that much in valley areas. There is something called a "Rain Shadow Effect" and what this does is if there is a mountain range between the ocean and a interior town, the rain will be stopped by the mountains which will create a dry-ish climate on the other side. It will still rain...but not as much as it did in Another. The climate is the same as an ocean city in Canada. So not much was explained to me before the geographer in me got a bit uneasy. 


Art:


I'm going to say it now, I've never been a fan of the big-eyed anime characters. They really do creep me out. But because this was an horror genre anime, it fit quite nicely. Once again, I am impressed with the animation in this. There were a few "whoopie" moments, but they did not hesitate on the gory bits. There was enough blood that literally made me look away. 


Sound:


Very nice opening. The song set the mood of the story very well. It was an eerie, but exciting and catchy song. The ending...not so much. I would've picked a more darker song than something that made me want to smile. This show is supposed to make you be at the edge of your seat and covering your mouth with your hand, not dance around like a ballerina. The rest of the soundtrack I wasn't paying much attention to since I was so focused on the scene and the dialogue, but at the one part I did listen to it, I felt it fit fine into the scene. 


Character:


Oh boy...my favourite. 


The characters didn't have a lot of emotion to them. Whenever someone died, their reaction wasn't there. There was no trauma involved. I agree, from someone who has gone through trauma, shock is part of it, and yes the characters went through that, but they moved on the next day like nothing ever happened. There was no fear in their eyes except that one girl who screamed. 


Mei is a stotic character. No emotions what so ever. Kouichi reminds me of Erwin from Attack on Titan for some strange reason. Izumi is actually a very likable character until the end. And many more characters have very...unexpected twist. You'll be surprised. 


Overall/Enjoyment:


It was okay. I'm not a fan of horror and have a strong phobia of horror movies and anything blood. This hasn't given me nightmares yet, so I think I'm good, but I won't be watching it again. However, I found myself at the edge of my seat the entire time (the joys of the horror genre). And at the end...let's just saw I was a bit mind blown. But like I said above, don't watch this if you have a fear of dolls and grossness. This show is rated R for a reason...make sure you know what you're getting into before watching it.


I give Another a B- or a 74% on the blood scale.

"Another" was the first anime of the horror, mystery genre I've ever watched. 
Because, in fact, I actually dislike watching horror movies due to various reasons. 
And after watching the first 4 episodes I thought about quiting it, because I thought, it would be kinda like the Final Destination Movies. I disliked those, because (in my opinion) the films and the story are quite focused on the way how those people die. I assumed after the first 4 episodes that would also be the case for Another...
Oh how wrong I was.
Story: 10/10
So like I said above, I actually assumed that the story would focus onthe death of those people. 

After watching the first 4 episodes, I (like i mentioned above), was about to quite this anime. The reason, why I kept watching it, was mainly, because I was extremely curious about the secret behind Misaki Mei. 

Unlike Final Destination this anime focuses not on the death of the persons, but rather on the, let's call it "curse" of the class 9c and how those people struggle to avoid it and finally, how to undo it. 


The story itself is very well written. Each episode of the anime feeds us viewers only little information, like puzzle pieces that we have to put together one after another, but keeping us all on the wrong path till the very end ,so, after each episode, we could basically screw the puzzle and start all over again.

The beginning was a bit slow, but after the first few episodes it quickly shifts into a way faster developing story that keeps you engaged and nail biting.  



*SPOILER*

And the plot twist at the end was beautifully done. 



The only things about the story I disliked are:


1) The beginning of the anime is quite slow. And all this "don't tell the new guy anything about this" is a bit annoying, cause they keep doing that for quite some time. 


2) The other thing is the ending. The end it self is nicely done, but the final 2-3 episodes are a bit overstretched and are kinda missing the right feeling for me.


I mean... 

*SPOILER* 

...Misaki could have just telled Sakakibara the name of the dead person, so they could have announced it. But no, let a huge bunch of  people die first, and than tell him afterwards.  I think, it would have been a way better ending, if they actually did, what I just said, and then show, how Sakakibara would react and how the would have proceeded to lift the curse.

When searching at night for anime I say to myself I'll watch one episode now and the rest tomorrow. This has always been my rule and I've stuck by this. However, When I watched the first episode of Another I couldn't help but to watch the next one and then the next and so on for the entire series. Before I knew it, it was 4 in the morning and I had watched the entire series. 
The story starts when the protagonist starts his new school but is bed ridden due to some illness he procures the day he was meant to join. He meetsa strange girl in the hospital at night (I know...cliched a bit). That's where he meets Misaki. When he finally goes to school, he realizes something very odd is happening in his class and his class mates are dieing accidentally. The story is about his year in class 3 and how he discovers the horrible fate that awaits anyone who has anything to do with class 3.


I'm going to crack down now and get straight into this. The story in this anime was amazing. Defiantly worth the 9 I gave it. I have no idea who wrote Another but bravo to you. It had some amazing ability to give me hints and clues to what was going on and eventually I had worked out what was going to happen and I made my predictions. I could not have been any more stupid. The story swiftly and neatly changed and more things came to light. I thought I had it worked out but then more things happened and my prediction was as useful as a bra for a four year old. The constant changing of the story kept me entertained and I could not stop watching it. 


Moving onto the art, I thought the drawing of the characters was pretty average for the year the anime was made. Nothing special yet I gave the art a 9. You must be thinking I'm retarded or something but no. The backgrounds were stunning. Truly worthy of a 10 (if not for the mediocre character design). The level of detail and care taken into making these backgrounds had me in awe. The artists also managed to achieve a very good dull, run down, ghost town sort of look by making wood look faded and metal objects rusty. This effect complimented the horror theme.


Sorry guys but I really haven't got much to say about the sound except that it's very fitting for the scenes that it's heard in. I usually skip the intros and outros of shows so again, sorry about that one. I will say though that scenes where it's very violent, it has eerie sound sin the background which add very well to the atmosphere.


I do think I've gone over the character's art a bit but the characters themselves are well defined as individual people. That might not make much sense but if you have watched bad anime with a crap ton of cliches then you will know that writers tend to get lazy and characters end up with very similar personalities, eradicating all variety and potential in the anime. Another does not have this problem since the characters have got their own personalities.


I enjoyed this anime alot and would recommend it to horror lovers with the promise of plenty of blood and suprise. My only criticisms is that this anime, with a few more episodes, could have some romance between the two protagonists. But I guess I'm just saying that as an aid fan of the horror/comedy/romance genre.


Overall I give the story a 9, Art a 9, Sound a 10, Character an 8, Enjoyment a 10 and the overall score a 9. These scores I decided whilst trying to think of the tastes of others in mind but personally I'd award this show a straight out 10. Ignore what everyone else says, this is the anime to be watching. 


If you're still reading at this point, thanks for reading my review.

Hey guys, my first review here. 
For my reviews, I will not mention the setting or summarize the plot, because people can read that on the page of the anime. 
I think that Another, is a very neat piece of work overall. I first started watching this series a few years back, and I actually dropped it after watching the first few episodes of the series. Man, am I glad to pick it back up. 
Story: 8/10
I gave the story of Another an 8 because I thought that it was rather slow-paced at the beginning section of the anime. Many people decide what anime theywant to watch next by looking at the genres of the anime. I personally like horror and mystery series, which is why I decided to give Another a try. There was definitely the mystery attribute during the whole anime, but I being the "patient" guy that I am, got somewhat frustrated after watching the first few episodes since nothing was really explained until the end. I am not going to spoil any part of the anime, and I would just like to say that Another has some of the most intense mystery and murder cliffhangers. 


Art: 9/10

Being from P.A. works, the art was just fantastic. One of the best attributes of this anime was the detailed quality of the characters. One thing that I really liked were the red eyes of Misaki Moe Mei (MMM). Obviously, her eye was not the only reason I gave the art section a 9. The background graphics were terrific as well. The wind blowing on the rooftop of the school and the detail of the leaves flying and blowing made the whole anime experience much more interesting. 


Sound: 7/10

You can tell that the producers behind this anime have definitely put a lot of effort behind choosing, selecting, and/or creating OSTs and songs for the opening, ending, and run-time music. Although I personally did not love the opening, I think that it really suits the vibe of the anime in general. Being a mystery and horror anime, the violin is an instrument that is utilized a lot. From the soundtracks of this song, especially at certain scenes where dread is jump on you from around the corner, the music that is played is very well matched. This factor of this anime further helps create the gloomy atmosphere of the anime with ease, and arouse feelings of dread and suspicion in the audience. The juxtaposition between the constant feelings of dread and the peaceful "ending" song provides a period of relaxing for the audience. 


Character: 9/10

Hard to explain why I gave this a 9 without spoiling. I'll just say that each of the characters that gets introduced actually play a major role in the story. At the start, you get introduced to a medium cast of characters, and despite mostly being side characters, the plot is constructed in such a way that each of the characters actually matter later on in the story FOR A WHILE. It is very likely for the audience to get confused over the characters at the beginning. Some reactions that I had were: "Why are they doing that?" "Who is she or WHAT is she?" "What.". And guys, get confused, but don't stop watching. It gets explained. 


Enjoyment: 9/10

Couldn't stop watching after episode _. I really enjoyed this series, and it is one of the best tragedy pieces I have watched so far. 


Overall: 9/10

If you like horror and mystery, by all means give this a try. Just hang in there, and do not drop it like I did once after watching a few episodes, and I am sure you will not regret watching this series.

As an avid horror fan, I am a sucker for horror anime when done right.The world of anime has not really seen a good horror one since the Higurashi series.
 So, when I first heard of Another getting an anime series, I had really high expectations from it.
    So, quitting all the blahblah's, here goes my review~
  Another starts with the male protagonist, Kouichi Sakahibara, coming to the dreaded class 3, in the summer of 1998. Soon he grows suspicious of the fearful atmosphere and the fact that his classmates are hiding something from him. Meanwhile, hefinds a beautiful and lonely girl named Mei Misaki and learns the fact that she might have something to do with the mysterious deaths occuring to the students of class 3 each year.

Plot- 5/10...The story is somewhat unique, however flawed. A lot is left unexplained, like how does the dead one really come every year? How can Mei see death if her eye is just that of a doll? Also, towards the end, it basically becomes a boring survival bloodfest.


Characters- 4/10...arguably the weakest part of the show. Another has a large set of characters, and so no one gets the time to develop much over 12 episodes. A couple more episodes just to flesh out the side characters would have made it more enjoyable.The standout part was the budding relationship between the two main characters, which was nicely done. Misaki's backstory gives the character some depth, but Kouichi was really the weak link. Often stoic and bland, in the final episode he was basically talking in phone calmly being surrounded by fire, which doesn't make much sense.


Animation- 8.5/10....the strongest part of the show. Nicely drawn characters makes the gory scenes a tad easier to watch.


Soundtrack- 5/10....meh, nothing really to talk about this, was average at best.


Overall- 5/10....Another fails miserably as a horror series.At certain points, it tries too hard to scare the audience, by showing random images of dolls and using a scary soundtrack. The death scenes, though gory, are really laughable (not to mention most of the deaths are of piercing something through the neck).

  However, it succeeds in the mystery part, and with a decent plot twist, keeps you right on the edge. Also, the side characters were interesting, a fact non existent in most other anime.The ending is decent enough and gives the series a proper closure.

So, despite its flaws, and the fact that it should have had more episodes, you will enjoy this anime if you like good,old fashioned mystery elements. However, if you go into this anime for the chills, you may feel disappointed to some extent.

I'm extremely skeptical when it comes to any sort of animated entertainment and horror. I went it into this anime having been told this was one of the best horror anime, and I have to say I was slightly disappointed. To be fair, I never asked why it was so good so for all I knew, this anime couldve been praised for things other than its horror setting. And that was exactly how I felt.
Story: 8/10
The story follows the bland and over curious Kouichi, a new transfer student to extremely strange and eerie high school, as he meets the mysterious and beautiful Mei, a girlwho seems to be non existent to everyone else in the class. His curiosity about the school and Mei leads him down some dark paths and he learns about forces which no one can comprehend, all of which he ends up trying to battle with the aid of his classmates. It sounds like a really interesting story but I feel like it wasn't told as well as it could have.


I found the the first episode to be boring. Like really boring. And for me, first impressions have a really large impact on my opinion of an anime, especially if said anime is 12 episodes long. So even though subsequent episodes made the story more interesting, I continued to have a somewhat negative opinion of the anime as I continued to watch it. However, having said that, this anime has some really freaking good cliffhangers, the only thing which really kept me interested in investing my time in this anime. As one episode ended, I wanted desperately to know what going to happen the next episode despite the fact that the episodes themselves were somewhat boring to me. It's only after things are finally explained that I really began to appreciate what the first few episodes were about, and thus my first impressions had been erased quite a bit.


But one of the things which made me dislike the first few episodes is the fact that I felt like the anime tried way too hard to be a horror. It continually placed you in really cliché settings like a dark under-funded hospital or a shop full of creepy looking dolls. To me, it wasn't scary at all and I would've much preferred it just be a regular mystery anime rather than a mysterious horror.


Sound: 9/10


While on the topic of Another trying too hard to be a horror, I want to talk about the background music, particularly in the first few episodes. The background music itself was actually pretty darn good; it was ominous, mysterious, fear-evoking. However, I felt like it was overused and definitely used in scenes which didn't need such background music. If I recall correctly, there is a scene where a few of Kouichi's new classmates visit him in the hospital to say hi in he first episode. Sure they act a little strangely, but I really did not see the need for the music to be that typical to any sort of horror medium. This only really seems to be a problem for me the first few episodes because as the series went on, I found that the music started to fit the scenes a lot more appropriately and the horror music was used a lot less, making it more scary when it was actually played.


I watch english dubs and I have to say that I probably should have watched the subbed version instead, especially seeing that it was better than the dub in the OVA which I could not find dubbed. It's not to say they were particularly bad. The voice acting was decent. No one felt out of place but at the same time, no one stood out as being good. However, I did like Mei's voice acting. Despite being kind of bland due to her "I don't really give a shit" attitude, it really made her all the more mysterious.


Characters: 6/10


This is one of the more major problems I had when I was watching Another. Aside from Mei and her mysteriousness, all the other characters were bland, uninteresting, and at times just plain annoying. None of the characters are really given much development, if any at all, and even if they were given development, most of it led nowehere. In particular, I want to point out Izumi's development. She's initially shown as cold and heartless but after things are explained you realise that she knows she comes off as cold and heartless but it is for a good cause. Its an interesting development, however it leads nowhere. There is also her connection to Kouichi prior to knowing him at their current highschool which was introduced but had absolutely no connection to the story, well at least one that I couldn't see and which still bugs me quite a bit.


Art: 10/10


This is one of the things that this anime does extremely well. It's beautiful in just every scene and it's heavenly in the scenes where it wants to be beautiful. While I wasn't scared at all, the art did a really good job of compensating for it by always having me slightly on edge because the art was more realistic and vivid. This also translated to more gruesome moments when people die, especially since deaths are kind of creative in this anime. Seeing how well the art was done when somebody's neck was pierced by a sharp object or stabbed by more than enough knives really made it seem all the more gruesome.


Enjoyment: 8/10


As I said before, the first few episodes were boring and this anime tried too much to be scary. However, as events are properly explained and the anime tried less and less to be scary, I satrted to appreciate it a lot more, especially the final two episodes which really explored some pretty dark themes and which were extremely intense.


I hope I helped you in the decision as to whether you want to watch this anime or not. Any feedback is greatly appreciated!

My first review in MAL!!
When I first saw the synopsis of Another ,it seemed to have a really interesting plot. Not many animes deal with this sort of school horror involving superstitions of the type found in many old institutions.
The start though painfully slow ,managed to keep me interested long enough to reach the third episode where things first started to get interesting..
Things start to pick up once Sakakibara learns the truth about Misaki and why nobody else seems to recognise her existence .The suspense and potential horrors in store for me really excited me.
*MINOR SPOILER*
The ending of the show though turned out to bereally disappointing.Almost all of the deaths occurred due to simple lack of communication between the classmates.When the stakes are so high you would think the class would act together. But what we actually got to see was a mindless and baffling blood bath, all of which could have been prevented..\n\n
All in all, the show never really manages to fulfil its potential.Most of the deaths are comical rather than scary.The creators seem to be under a delusion that amount of blood=horror.The heavy handed direction of the show irked me a lot.There was no subtlety.At frequent intervals,random shots of creepy dolls were shown almost to artificially crank up the horror levels.\n
As for the characters themselves,with the exception of Misaki,none of the characters are likable at all.Stupid teenagers are a common sight in such gore fests,but some of the actions of the students were really baffling.As for the main lead ,Koichi was so painfully dense that I shouted at him through the screen many times!!\n
Overall ,I would give it a 7 rating.The story was awesome and had loads of potential,but lack of proper direction and a weak ending pretty much ruined the show for me.Still,I would recommend watching Another.When it touches its high points,it's worth a watch.\n\n
P.S:The scene in the last episode where Koichi, standing in the middle of a raging fire, finally finds a network on his mobile and calls Misaki is the most unintentionally funny moment I've ever watched in an anime :P

Kouichi Sakakibara arrives from Tokyo to his new high school, from the very first moment he makes a lot of friends but he notices that something is not right, one of the desks is empty. One day he realizes there’s a mysterious girl at the school, she wears a patch in her left eye, seems distant from everything, nobody pays attention at her even when she enters the classroom and sits at the empty desk. He decides to talk to her to find out what’s happening but his classmates warn him not get in contact with her, he just has to act like she doesn’texist. Ignoring this warning he contacts her and mysterious accidents begin his classmates. Kouichi finds out that all these strange events started 26 years ago and decides to know the beginning of this mystery.


I must say this anime got my attention until the last episode the problem is they don’t tell us what happened 26 years ago, why these strange accidents happen, who’s the responsible for all this to happen. Not even the way to avoid these accidents is clear. All these points make the story to be a bit complex and make it not a horror story at all, but very scheming. 


The main character, Kouichi Sakakibara y Mei Misaki, have a lot of punch together ad become nice, especially Mei. What surprises me when I watch horror anime is not just how the plot works, but how interesting the characters turn out to be. I mean, you see them first as their normal, peaceful state, but then, a situation strikes like lightning, taking a big impact. Usually, the reaction of character in horror anime never ceases to amuse me. I just think it's so unique how it not only shows the character's true nature, but also develops them as the show goes on.
With this anime however, it wasn't as pleasing on the character part. In fact, that was the weakest part.
So first off, since theplot is the reason for characters, I'll discuss that first. Another starts with a transfer student, a.k.a Kouichi Sakakibara, going to a new school in Class 3-3. First it seems normal and all that, but then he notices how one girl, Mei Misaki, is treated by her classmates as if she doesn't exist. Because of his curiosity as to why, he continues to associate with Mei more, causing dark turns relating to the students of Class 3-3.


The plot is pretty good, but how they portrayed it?  Well, it was okay. I mean, I did like the suspense shown when something happens, but the pacing was really, really slow. If you make a horror anime with suspense, you need to make it good enough for the watcher to stay and continue watching. Putting surprises once in a while is fine, but the rest of the plot itself needs to be interesting too. When I watched this, it felt like all scenes without the suspense element was just filler, until the anime reveals itself. There were times where I did not want to go through the boring dialogue and character. To be fair, I appreciated the dark theme like the show promised, but not the lack of interesting plot.


The art can be made up for the plot. I'm a fan of P.A. Works because I've always thought that their art was beautiful. They did a really good job of not just making the characters detailed, but the backgrounds and settings detailed and fitting for a dark theme. Definitely one of the strong points in this anime.


Well, now that we talked about the stronger elements of Another, let's talk about their weakest, character. When making a main character, I expect he or she to NOT be one of those cliche characters that don't make any change in the anime, whatsoever. Sadly, Another is just like that. At least with the main guy character, Kouichi Sakakibara. He's supposed to help out with the plot, to make it better, to develop the story. Instead, all he does is become curious about a situation, but doesn't really find a way to solve the problem. And he lacks personality too. 

Talking about Mei Misaki though, she's way different. Honestly, she's the only character that I like in this anime. She has a mysterious personality, and that makes her character way creepier. She was the only one actually trying the support the plot and develop it, while everyone else was too busy being stupid. You can say whatever defense you want for the characters, but really? I don't see anything important in them except Mei Misaki. Don't believe me? Here's some evidence. 

One of the supporting characters, Izumi Akazawa, is an example of a character done wrong. She's supposed to be the in charge of the headcounts of the incidents happening in Class 3-3, but she's doing a horrible job of it. Her "backstory" wasn't even one bit sad, and in fact, it was confusing. The supporting characters aren't even helping. It's like all of them are fillers. The rest of the class had zero development and was only there so that they would have people for the deaths.


Sound? Same with characters--okay. The opening does have an amazing dark feeling that gets the show started which I did enjoy. The ending was weird. The suspense usually happens at the end, and then it gives us this slow, calm setting. It doesn't fit the ending at all. 


Okay, I know I might have not written the best review there is on this show, but I think my thoughts are reasonable. Do I want you to watch it? Depends. If you like horror and gore, go ahead, but you might not like the big amount of filler in there. Also, if you can stand the useless characters, then go ahead. I don't regret watching it, not at all. It's just, I expected a lot more to this. Honestly, they were heading into a really good direction, but then they somehow couldn't find their way and became completely lost.

'Another' is an anime that looks and feels like a great horror detective story. It puts the viewer in a camera room, displays some fucked up stuff on the screens and then expects you to work out what really happened. And just when you think you have an idea of what might be going on, 'Another' busts through the camera room door and starts violently slapping your face until you have no idea what's happening. It then leaves and shows you more fucked up stuff on the screens. And it does it well. 
The story is simple. It follows the life of 15 yearold Kouichi Sakakibara as he moves to Yomiyama North middle school at the beginning of the series.  He's a smart fellow who asks a lot of questions and quickly adapts to his new surroundings. He's also eager to adapt (iykwim) to Mei Misaki, his mysterious eye-patch wearing female classmate. Apparently though, that eye-patch isn't the only mysterious thing about her and as soon as Kouichi makes contact batshit crazy stuff starts to happen. This is your basic premise and the anime builds on that.


For a 12 episode horror series there's a lot of gore here. 'Another' has no qualms about precise, high quality bloody mayhem. This is a huge plus for any horror enthusiast. The way the story ties these bloody events together and slaps you with a plot twist after another is sure to keep you frosty. Spare pair of pants strongly recommended.


The characters are a strong point here. Kouichi is your typical kind of guy caught up in a series of events he does not understand. He tries to keep a straight face when shit gets real but we know that he's quaking underneath. Mei is an emotionless femme fatal who has Kouichi's undivided attention. Watching those two is like watching a National Geographic documentary of a hypnotized Lion following a disinterested Lioness half across the savannah with hyenas tearing animals apart in the background. Good stuff.


We also have a couple of notable supporting characters. The uptight tsundere Izumi Akazawa, the chick in charge of the class, who'd make a good friend to a rock or seaweed. An annoying addition to the cast but she does help make the series complete. The laid back Naoya Teshigawara who is actually a pretty cool character and always tries to help out in his own retarded way. Then there's bookworm Yukari Sakuragi who'd be handy to have around if you ever daydreamt during class (cough Kouichi cough) and forgot to take notes. 


There's a horde of other characters - women who like to get smashed on high quality alcoholic beverages, silent psychopathic types, old melodramatic geezers... you get the idea, it's a fun cast all around.


Now with all that said, 'Another' is not without its flaws. For starters this series is too short. It tries to deliver too much plot material in a very short amount of time (only 12 episodes). There was definitely room for more (think Higurashi) and the plot could have easily been spaced out to make this a 24 episode series. And as strong as the plot is ( a solid 9 imo) there are certain things that make the ending very anticlimactic. That is, the ending is unsatisfying and that is quite enough to knock down a point in the story section.


As for the rest - the art is flawless, the gore scenes captivating and the overall tone and art style complements the story well. The sound department however is slightly lacking. The sound effects and voice acting is good but the OST leaves room for improvement. I quite literally failed to notice it and the opening and ending songs don't fit to this particular anime AT ALL, imo. 


With all of the above mentioned, the enjoyment section deserves a solid 8 points. You will be intrigued, you might get scared depending on your disposition and sometimes you might just pause the video and ask yourself if that really just happened (dat daydream). A must see for horror fans. Generally however, I'd recommend this to anyone.


All in all, 8 points.


Thank you for reading!

Another（アナザー）is some kind of psychological/supernatural horror anime that has some scares here and there and a really, really, actually really bad OP. No, seriously, what the hell is that opening? It’s scarier than the whole concept of the anime. But anyway, let’s begin with the story concept. By the way, I’ll try my best to hinder spoilers.
Story Concept
Somewhere in Japan, we have a little town in the middle of nowhere called Yomiyama（夜見山）which is your plain, rural town. Then we have the protagonist, Sakakibara Kouichi（榊原恒一）, which is a guy with a disease called pneumothorax, which is why he goes to Yomiyama. Or maybe he went becausehis father was working in a research in India…? Well whatever it is, it’s not actually the focus of the series (I think). The thing is, he’s transferred to a Middle School in Yomiyama, and that’s where the story actually begins. The issue with the classroom that he gets transferred to is, it’s a cursed classroom. Meaning, real gruesome deaths of adolescents because of the curse. Anyway, we also have Misaki Mei（見崎鳴）, a heroine loli that has deep meaning in the story. And she has an eye-patch. There are also a whole cast of classmates, their relatives and the protagonists’ relatives, but of course I won’t name all of them. Specially because they are not that important anyway.


Now then, the concept of a cursed classroom would not be bad, until the moment you notice that it makes no sense to have a dozens of deaths of children (and their relatives) from the same classroom and nobody actually giving a crap. Well that’s what happens on Another. For some reason, every death goes unnoticed by everyone besides the characters of the story, as if it’s a given that, if you are in a cursed classroom and you might die, you have to keep on that classroom. Couldn’t the school just close down and the students go live in Another city? Noticed the lame pun?


What I’m trying to say is, the anime itself states that you the curse only affects those in the perimeter of the town, so yes it would be completely okay to blow up the whole school building. It can’t be that it’s the sole school in the whole town. But then, maybe I’m misunderstanding the concept of the curse, and it would actually pass on to the next classroom/next school building. Whatever is the “rules” of that game, it feels stupid anyway when you have a dozens of children and 3, 4 adults in a situation of life and death every god damned year and still no one in the rest of the city ever realizes or helps. It’s as if it’s a secret. Now that’s something I take my hat off for Shiki; even being the slightly rushed adaptation that it was, it had that awesome moment when the villagers finally realized and accepted the truth of what was happening, and reacted to it. In a gruesome manner. Anyway on to the next part.


Art Concept


It’s anime, so I believe it goes without saying how the characters’ art concept is. And yes, sometimes the art gets really bad, and you can easily spot deformed characters in the background. Or maybe it was intentional for the freaky effect?


The scenarios are okay, actually. I’m no art specialist and I actually don’t have much of an opinion, but I don’t remember backgrounds being bad.


On a fast note (since I’ll be talking about this on a special part), the deaths have no censoring as far as I recall, so yea lots of blood on your screen… Sometimes a bit too much. Not that this is a bad thing, of course.


Audio Concept


I am, once again, no specialist in this audio thingy, but I can tell you that, being death as the nature of the anime, it has really dull and unimpressive BGMs throughout the whole time, except when someone’s dying. Usually you get a really drastic change of music, which may or may not scare you (mostly for it’s 140% increase in volume), and that music is usually fitting for the death scene. Wait, I like the ring “Death Scene” has. From now on I’ll be referring to the deaths as Death Scenes.


Death Scene Concept


Let’s be frank out of the bat. Most of the Death Scenes are ridiculous, not to say obvious. I mean, the protagonist talks to a girl that has no name (or at least is not important at all, because I don’t remember it) beside a truck with a big window glass on it… Oh, don’t forget the glass was not fastened on anything. Yep, the moment you see it, you’ll immediately notice a Death Scene is coming― except it had no death! What a combo breaker, for a series that kills a character per episode.


Death Scenes, besides being quite weird and ridiculous, are also forcibly gruesome. In most Death Scenes, the dying character will agonize and agonize, and you don’t know if you should smirk at the silliness or be horrified at the fact the Death Scenes are actually well-looking (as in, good art) while the plain scenes are not. Well, I just generalized. Like I said in the Art Concept part, it’s not a bad-looking anime. It just suffers the same problem as every other anime: low budget. So they pay more in the Death Scenes, and less in the other scenes. Happens all the time. Anyway off to the next section.


Living Zombies in the (Burning) Cursed Inn!! (some spoilers here, you’ve been warned)


…Yea I just wanted to go for a weird name. Truth be told, most of Another was the horror of “dying at any time, being hopeless before death”, which might also be the sole redemption of the show itself. But then, because of story details I can’t spoil, you get a whole classroom of students walking like zombies (not in the literal sense) around the inn, trying to kill you with brooms and… whatever happens to be in their hands. Of course I understand the purpose was to show what a human being can do when facing imminent death but… please, could you walk like you actually want to kill? Felt really preposterous when dozens of students started to close in around the protagonists like zombies. Or maybe I’m just out of the loop and zombies are really fast? I haven’t really played any new zombie games after Resident Evil 4 (lol quite some time, I know).

And then, on the very last episode, we get the epitome of nonsensical happenings and a exploding inn. By the way does that inn have gasoline inside it's walls or something? I can't see Another way (Another pun!) to have it so explosive. Even the lightnings were overboard, and in the very end I expected more of a drama than what we get. To be honest, there's not much to say about the last episode; it's just weird. Well, I've seen worse, and I'm sure everyone did, too, but that doesn't mean I should just say it's fabulous. Because it wasn't.


Conclusion


This anime doesn’t deserve more than 6/10. It does have it’s ups and downs, but it quite lost it's way twisting around the mystical and the horror, and in the end I would've been happier if the protagonist went Chris Reddfield mode and shoot everyone in the head while running around the explosive mansion with his girl. Oh yea that would've been one awesome ending. Nothing like sarcasm to finish a review. :P

With its creepy atmosphere and stylistically graphic deaths, Another is a wickedly fun horror ride. It effectively (and gleefully) uses horror tropes to provide plenty of chills, and has enough mystery to keep you guessing from beginning to end. While it is not close to being subtle or refine, its insatiable desire to entertain and its love for bloodletting make it a gory good time. Too bad it doesn't have much staying power.
The basic set up is something we've seen plenty of times in horror. Our protagonist Kouichi Sakakibara moves from the big city, in this case Tokyo, to a small town to live withrelatives because his father is a way, and his mother is well... diseased. Due to lunge problems, Kouchi enters high school late, an has spent a good amount of time in the hospital. When he finally does begin attending school he finds that a girl he met the day before is release from the hospital, Mei Misaki, is one of his classmate in class 3-3. However, nobody else in class acknowledges her existence... or maybe they are not aware of it (dun dun dun). At the same time Kouichi can't help but think he is being kept in the dark about something by his classmates. Soon, a string of gruesome deaths begin to take place, all of which are somehow connected to class 3-3.


The story provides plenty of mysteries for viewers to view on. What exactly is going on with class3-3? What are Kouichi's classmates hiding from him and why? Has Kouchi visited the town before? If he had, is it somehow connected to the current situation? Is Mei real, a figment of Kouichi's imagination, or a spirit from beyond? These questions arise and keep you interested in what might happen next. And you know you won't get the answers until late into the story, because the show has a fondness of being cryptic and throwing in red herrings. This is good because it allows the show to maintain the suspense throughout its run; keeping the viewership wondering what exactly is going on. Even with bits and pieces of the truth being revealed, there is a veil of mystery that only gets pulled away in the show's final episodes.


That said, the show is hardly subtle in its handling of its mysteries. In fact, they are almost always in your face. The plot may as well be yelling "SOMETHING STRANGE IS HAPPENING!" sometimes. This is especially true for the early episodes before the plot really kicks in. Most of those episodes consisted of Kouchi's classmates dodging his questions or downright refusing to answer them. While this does keep a good sense of mystery in the early episodes, it can get a bit frustrating when the show seems like it is about to give answers and fakes-out at the last second. Luckily, it does have the sense to actually give answers before your patience runs out, and provides plenty of gruesomely fun deaths along the way. Even when the story gets rolling, however, there is a distinct lack of subtlety.


The deaths in Another are as entertaining as they are bloody, and boy, are they bloody. Whether they be homicide, suicide, or accident so improbable that they had to be of supernatural decent; the deaths are extremely graphic. However, rather than being gratuitous to the point of off-putting, the deaths are nightmarish spectacles that are equal parts shocking and gleeful. This is largely due to the frenetic energy they are directed with; the deaths are easily the most exciting moments in the show. The fact that majority of the show is talky and cryptic makes the straightforward, matter-of-fact death scenes all the more effective, in all their deranged blood-soaked glory. Admittedly, the energy the deaths are directed with can be a double-edged sword. Sometimes they can end up being more comedic than frightening. Still, the show cannot be accused of being boring or uninspired.


Another is a show that is far more concerned with its plot than it is with its characters. As far as main characters go, Kouichi is actually kinda plain. You get the impression he is generally a good guy, with a rather convenient fascination with the strange and mysterious; especially with Mei and the ominous circumstances surrounding class 3-3. Outside of what the plot requires him to be, he doesn't have much personality, honestly. Mei is the more interesting of our two protagonist, as she is surrounded by mystery a good portion of the show. Her back story also gives a reasonable explanation for her peculiar personality. However, she can be too calm and reserved; her stoic demeanor makes her a bit too distant to completely relate to. The rest of the cast just feel kind of like fodder for the body count. Even more important characters like the head of countermeasures (of what I won't say because of spoilers) Izumi Akazawa, and Kouichi's other school yard friends feel kind of like walking corpses, and you half expect one of them to drop dead at any moment. The problem with the characters is that they are mechanisms of the plot, rather than figures that you can get invested in.


The art of Another looks really good. Admittedly, the character designs fall into the same glossy, attractive look that all the shows from studio P.A. Works have. This isn't a bad thing, however, as they are still very polished and never get off model; even when they are going bat-shit crazy. More impressive are the elaborate backgrounds that make up the world of Another. What should be just a mundane school and a mundane town, instead look downright ominous because of the fantastic art direction. The use of lighting and sometimes subdued color pallet (there are plenty of bright moments in the show) does wonders for the show's atmosphere. The music is also well composed and fittingly creepy. The thing is, though, Another wields its soundtrack like a sledgehammer. There is rarely a time when the music is used with subtlety, and often plays very loud at times that you should be scared. That is not to say it isn't effective, it is much of the time; but also overplayed.

Sometimes tragedies are unavoidable, sometimes they are necessary to get a point across. Another accomplishes that with as many victims as it needs, though the results can be a bit on the brainless side when the cast is a bunch of school kids.
STORY: I think it's about time to put something next to the Higurashi series in terms of being a successful horror anime, no Another isn't scary though neither was Higurashi, but Another functions extremely well as a horror story despite some hic ups here and there. Another is 2012's first and maybe only horror anime to come out, but damn, it's a blessingthat it didn't end up like it's blood soaked victims and becomes one of 2012's better series.


Another is about Koichi Sasakibara who goes to live with his aunt and grandparents in the small town of Yomiyama which hosts his new particular school, where his mother grew up while his father goes on a trip to India. Though his arrival to school is delayed by a medical problem and has to go to the hospital. There he meets Misaki Mei and there is where it all begins, from random deaths to getting to know your fellow "nonexistent", and a tragedy that occurs yearly that takes the lives of those in classroom 9-3. Sasakibara will be going through a lot with the viewers in tow. 


By the viewer going through some trials I mean the anime takes it time building up to one of the biggest reveals in the show, it's really jarring on one's patience and even frustrating as everything around the oblivious main character that happens just makes you want to slap him silly, and Misaki Mei herself doesn't help other than lead you to believe in the misleading (I wonder who's dead, it may seem obvious but it actually isn't what you'd think, making it into a great twist), making it almost a red herring in a way.

Misaki herself is the biggest source of the anime's vagueness and it's biggest turn of events. But her personally, a very stoic one to the point of being a stiff (But metaphorical and literal if you count the animation) and an emotionless robot, can easily pull you out of tense heavy scenes with her lack of reaction, she only truly emotes well towards the end of the show.

But by the halfway point, Misaki and Sasakibara become something of an unofficial couple, and their relationship will make you want to root for them, especially for what their future has in store. The anime doesn't put too much focus on their relationship as a couple like how a romance anime would do, but thankfully stays on track with the initial story with this relationship being a very strong character growth for the both of them.


And speaking of some faulty characterizations, the class itself, with the exception of some of the individuals stepping up to bigger role from being background characters, is a big bunch of idiots, or at least where the series first big reveal is concerned as their decision for handling their calamity is borderline retarded.

But when everything falls apart, their panicked states and desperate actions become fascinating to watch, especially during the series explosive end.


The show is not for the faint of heart, the death scenes are usually very brutal, especially the first surprising one, blood is no stranger in Another.

Even with all of the death and blood coming from everywhere, the anime somehow manages to crowbar in one of anime's biggest and most irritating cliches: the beach episode... Yep, though it end with another death, this is something that obviously had no place to offer other than fan service.

And very, very occasionally, the show actually has a brief sense of humor, especially in one very bizarre day dream Sasakibara has (One that could actually happen in context of the show).


The show also has a couple of bad habits like withdrawing important stuff until the end that really needed to have been mentioned sooner otherwise would seem like it was made up right on the spot, even though one moment is actually hinted at throughout the entire anime, making the final twist quite the eye opener.

Not to mention a few cliches, like for example: When a huge reveal is about to be uncovered, right at the very second it gets into it, the show is interrupted and said reveal get postponed, and sometimes postpones into the next episode, and, during the beginning of the series, the anime obnoxiously throws in completely random shots of creepy looking dolls, but it's not totally annoying and when it's gone it's definitely not missed.


But overall, Another is an effective horror story, the set ups, the tone, and especially the audio is all great. It's a series that grows better with each episode, even with it's cringe worthy moments both good ones and bad ones, Another becomes one of anime's few true horror series.


ANIMATION: P.A. Works, the guy responsible for series such as Angel Beats and Clannad have once again prove themselves to be quite the talented group of artists. Everything looks extremely dark and gloomy, making the visual experience one for the horror books. The character designs are diverse and distinctive (The character designs are done by Noizi Ito, the same person who did the designs for The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya and Shakugan no Shana) so overall there's nothing dull or boring to look at that's not unintentional. However, when actual movement is in talks, it is mostly severely lacking as there is little to almost no movement at all, some episodes even start off with a still frame that can last for minutes. But when the gruesome deaths come around, expect no corner cutting, it's done in horrific detail.


SOUND: As with the animation, it's sounds as creepy and spooky as any good horror story should, as it ties up the strings called the atmosphere of the anime quite nicely. But my only complaint is the opening theme, an out of place pop song by Annabel, though is still a decent song anyway.

Voice acting is decent too.


OVERALL:


The Good:

+ Great atmosphere, very creepy and well set up.

+ Initial episodes lead up a very good twist and the series improves from there on.

+ The growing relationship between the main characters is one that makes you want to cheer them on.


The Mixed:

+/- Good character designs and an overall dark and gloomy feel that matches perfectly with the atmosphere / Limited animation all around.

+/- The audio greatly reinforces the overall feel of the anime. / The anime sometimes over uses it to compensate ordinary scenes.

+/- Misaki grows from being a plot device and into major character. / Her personality can take you out of the gruesome scenes when the most she emotes is an annoyed look.


The Bad:

- The beginning can be quite a strain on one's patience.

- The actions of the class of 9-3 are mostly big helpings of stupidity and frustration.

- A beach episode, in a horror anime... Seriously?


There is one thing I'm seriously hoping that doesn't occur, countless sequels. This is pretty much the Final Destination of anime, though I hope it won't become that literally with mediocre sequel after sequel.

Thunder's review nr.5: Another
Did you heard that sound? No? Are you sure I... wait do you feel it? That chill in the air.. what are you doing!? Wait!! Ahhhh... why.. grrh why? Wait you do not know? What!? Why are asking me?! You are the ghost or something! Can't I get any explanation?! Oh well, at least we had some time together, despite you being such lifeless and cold individual. (Then he died in terrible agony)
Ladies and gentlemen, after this terrible intro that could summarize what's this anime is like I gladly welcome you to this review of Another.
The Story 4/10
The whole show feel likea good old horror movie. It basically have everything that characterize one as such. Creepy atmosphere: check, pale and strange characters: check, small town: check, beach fanservice episode: che... ah it is an anime after all. Despite the show being very dark and quite violent sometimes it still have some stereotypes that a lot of works in the anime media share, but they are a little bit turned down here. Thanks to that this anime achieved serious and creepy atmosphere, route that very few anime choose which is actually quite refreshing. Feeling of an old horror movie definitely is a great merit to Another. Although sometimes it may try a bit to hard to be as dark as possible.


The setting itself isn't that original neither for an anime or a horror movie. Your classical small town with secret that everybody want to keep for themselves. Our main protagonist is a transfer student, he doesn't understand what's going on and know just as much as we do. Story is about him discovering this mysterious curse that plague his new class for over a decade and trying to solve it. I think that curse itself is interested enough to keep us engage. There are many rules that apply to it and our poor students, with our MC Kouichi Sakakibara on the head of the group bringing new things to the table every episode. Sadly, this show have a hard time trying to surprise us, actually there are few series I've seen that are so predictable. We can easily guess who die next or what probably will happen at the end of the episode and all that without thinking too much.


Sadly I can't say that Another fulfilled its role as a horror. If you are afraid of the people dying randomly out of the blue, you should be fine. Especially if you're afraid of blood, much blood. Otherwise if you're looking for something scarier that just brutal violence you won't find it here. That's saddening me even more because it feels like the great atmosphere that this anime posses is wasted. We're left with mysteriously looking but empty shell.


Curse itself is sadly never explained to us as much as it should. I was thinking that it's fine if they keep all the explanations until the end when they want to end everything with a huge BANG. And when bang is a right word to describe the ending it wasn't the kind of bang I wanted to see. We can say that it was kind of incomplete bang. Ending is very open ended, with a lot things unexplained and what's worse nothing constantly resolved. It wouldn't surprise me if we would get Another II and it would have ended exactly the same way as its predecessor, that's how typical horror movies work and that's how good mystery or horror shows should NOT work.



The Art and the Animation 7/10

Another have a quite nice dark art style. Everything seems dark and depressing even when the sun is up, which suits this anime perfectly. Backgrounds are well done and everything seems decently detailed. Animation itself is nothing special but it can get very good when some death scene kicks in. It's a very gory anime and if you are not used to see well animated violence it may shock you.


Characters could use a little more details. Everybody look just as your another average person with pale skin (Yes, everyone are pale). Presenting average persons looks may suit some horror movie but animations here don't have amount of facial details that can help us to distinguish different characters from each other. There is always something more needed, that's why anime with unique art styles are made. When overall art style here is quite nice it is generic when it comes to characters and that's sad.



The sound 7/10

Music is creepy and contributes a lot to the atmosphere and enjoyment of the whole show. There aren't any outstanding tracks but there aren't any bad either, I will give soundtrack good score just because it works really well with this show. Opening was ok, a little mysterious and creepy(I really overuse that word in this review)song but it was more of a contrast to the show than intro that suited what's going on. On the other hand I found the ending song unskippable. It have still images in it but I did not mind that and I just sat there relaxed and enjoyed this beautiful and calm song as my soul lifted itself to heaven.


I found voice acting monotone and boring but I think we have to blame dialogues for it, not voice actors.



The Characters 3/10

I can't say that characters presented in this show does not suit its atmosphere because they do. Most of them are depressing and creepy teenagers. It's hard to find someone that isn't seriously sick, doesn't have problem with his family or friends and etc... But a lot of characters didn't have any background story at all. Death scenes may be very well animated and music in them suitable but they have little impact when we know next to nothing about people dying. Also show try to show us reasons for which we supposed to care for characters but they are weak, the strongest of them all is probably this: 10 second long dream or memory(who knows) of one girl that probably fallen in love and worry about her brother (no explanations why).


Both main and supporting cast are composed mostly, if not only of one and two dimensional characters. Most of them are quite boring and even way that most of them talk is boring and monotone. The only character I kind of liked was girl with the eyepatch (Misaki) she was kind of lifeless but at least she had some decent background story surrounding her.


My greatest issue with characters is certainly our main character, Kouichi Sakakibara. He's completely average teenager with no useful attitudes whatsoever and some sickness that makes him spend a lot of time in hospital (and give us some reason to care about him). He even looks completely normal (only a little pale of course). Just as the horde of similar anime characters he's that nice guy with brown and slightly spiky hair. Kouichi and all others characters are a little strange bunch of people. If you're a high school student and see someone brutally dying for the first time, how much time does it take for you recover from shock? Weeks, maybe days if you're a tough one? Well, it takes around 10 seconds for our main and supporting cast which is highly unrealistic. Some unnamed characters panic somewhat but our brave heroes act like nothing happened very next hour.


Those characters suit strange atmosphere of Another perfectly and honestly they are so serious I have to give them some credit for that. 3/10



The Enjoyment 6/10

Despite lacking in areas of story and characters, every aspect in the show added to the creepy and dark atmosphere of Another, which I enjoyed. If you like dark anime you will probably find it at least decently enjoyable just as me, otherwise there's nothing for you here. If you dislike gore you will have serious problem watching this anime because, violent deaths are high points in it. I probably would have enjoyed this anime more if it weren't as predictable and if mystery element wasn't that random.



Overall 5/10

Watching Another wasn't a complete waste. At least it was decently entertaining. Too bad that it weren't something better, it's nice to have mysteriously and interestingly looking shell but what's most important is always hidden insight. Another is a great example of a show that is so bad that it actually becomes enjoyable watch.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Hmm... What makes a good, thrilling tale of horror?
Yes, that's a pretty blanket question right there--and quite subjective to boot. However, I find myself rarely watching anything horror-related nowadays because it's all too narrow-minded for me. One example is that of the slasher sub-genre, which I find myself always none too fond of since I like to get to know the characters as more than one-dimensional stereotypes, and I only believe character death should either to come with some sort of attribution later on within the grand scheme of the story or serve as a lesson for the audience.
In other words,I believe that a good horror movie/show should be more about the atmosphere and gravity of a situation, with involving characters that the audience can relate to so that there can be hope that said characters will be okay by the end.


Another, originally written by Yukito Ayatsuji and adapted by P.A. Works, addresses some of my points in a positive manner, but also others in a rather mediocre or even negative manner. Overall, it's a fairly mixed bag, and I will attempt to address as much as I can without stepping too far into spoiler territory.


First off, there's the plot. In summary, during the year of 1972, there was a popular girl named Misaki in Class 3-3 who suddenly died under unknown circumstances. Her spirit, haunting the class from the year after onward, causes an annual "calamity" to occur where everyone who is or once was part of the class--both students and teachers alike--to die horribly in various accidents with each passing month. Jump to 1998 and a new student, Kouichi Sakakibara, soon realizes that there is a girl in his class who the other members claim "doesn't exist," known as Mei Misaki. From there, Kouichi is thrown into the fearful, ominous calamity himself where death happens to be none too kind to strangers...


I will say this: the concept for this plot does look pretty potentially exciting on paper (very Final Destination-meets-The Grudge, if I do say so myself), and, for the most part, Another does, indeed, deliver on this; however, there is definitely some padding here-and-there, as there needs to be room for suspense in just about any horror, right? Although, I will also admit that the suspense can seem a bit ridiculous, with musical cues sometimes coming across as rather overbearing or--at worst--hilarious. Nonetheless, the execution of this story does accomplish its goal to thrill and excite, but its really the cast that becomes the focal point of how things truly turn out.


Kouichi and Mei are certainly solid--perhaps even above-average--quality; they are a cool duo and I managed to find myself pretty attached to them along the way. However, it's the ensemble cast that I have plenty of issues with...


I conclude the major problem stems from the fact that this is only a 12-episode anime, and there's a whole classroom full of kids that I'm supposed to know well and feel concern for--but that just didn't happen while I was watching this show. Granted, the deaths could be gruesome, and I didn't want anyone to die, but I didn't feel that I got to notice any of them as bona fide characters--just a collective body count. Heck, even those that were shown more often than others didn't really get enough time devoted to them, either on-screen or in dialogue; it became such a dilemma for me, in fact, that I tended to like certain classmates over others solely based upon their individual hair styles. "Oh, golly! I hope the girl with the long, brown hair and PJs doesn't die! Hooray, she didn't!" (Truth be told, she really didn't.)


Moving on, the art is nice to look at; it is P.A. Works, after all. Speaking of the art, I think the real reason I didn't want any of the characters to die was because the designs were done by Noizi Ito, who also did the original artwork for such classics as Suzumiya and Shakugan no Shana. It's all just so... moe--though, trust me, it all still works out fashionably well, given the included creepy darkness and pasty color palette.


Although I was kind of making fun of the music before, I actually really liked it overall. When it worked, it really worked, and the ending song is just so pleasant, yet oh, so eerie, too. I do, however, believe that some scenes may have acted better without any music playing in the background (such as inside the store from the second episode) to keep things from getting too ridiculous, instead utilizing the scene's own strength to capture its audience, but I digress.


As I stated before, Another is truly a mixed bag. Those who like a little bit of everything in their horror from creeping to slashing will probably enjoy this ride for all it's worth; I know I most certainly did. Nonetheless, the major faults should not be overlooked, and while there are some nit-picks as seen by others that I could address, I dare not quash anymore of the mystery and--sometimes chuckle-worthy--suspense that this show has to offer.


Another gave me just enough of what I wanted to keep me happy, and as of right now, that's all I could ever ask for~

26 years ago a student from Yomi North's class 3 grade 9 passes away.  The next day however someone in the class says he's still alive. . . as the year goes on others agree that he exist until the time the student graduates.  From this point on class 3 grade 9 has been known as the class closest to death.
This is the pretext for Another.
I would consider Another to be the first horror anime I've seen (Thinks back to School Days *shudders*) but regardless I would say that it's a very well put together piece of work.
The first arc so to speakof Another starts off with a scene of one of our main characters Sakakibara Kouichi in a hospital bed surrounded by his classmates.  Seems normal enough. After he's discharged from the hospital he meets a girl, Misaki Mei on the hospital's elevator.  When he goes to school a few weeks later he sees her and goes to talk to her although his classmates strongly object him doing so.  From this event we start getting the meat behind Another's story. 


We start to ask questions to ourselves such as why do they act as if she's nonexistent? Is she a ghost? Whaat's going on? Is how you start to feel basically. You  may also start to wonder why there's a few seconds of zooming on on panels of broken glass windows, and why there's so many dang creepy dolls...  Although these shots may seem random they are fully intentional and provide good foreshadowing for what's to come later in the episode, or series.


The second arc of the show is where Another's masterful storytelling really comes together.  Once the background on class 3 grade 9's story comes to light is where the story really picks up with one of the major questions of *Spoiler* (Who is dead?)  This arc is very powerful in the way that it addresses some complex moral issues on the value of life, in a way that's subtle yet powerful.  Although others may disagree and think that people are just killing people there's nothing deep in that is where I think that everyone is entitled to their own thoughts and opinions and this is mine.  


All in all Another's storytelling style manages to hit you with plot twists left and right to keep you on  your toes, and just when you start to think you've figured out the story, your hit with a cliffhanger which jumbles up your thinking leaving you feeling pretty mindfucked so to speak. 


I don't have much to say about the characters in Another, just that they played their part I guess, even though some of them weren't around for long. . . The main characters Sakikabara and Mei were good but Mei really caught my attention.  I don't watch horror anime often but her personality really appealed to me.  I like the fact how she's mysterious, reserved, and is able to maintain a rational outlook on things.  Even though there's not much change in the characters they're fine the way they are.  


The art for Another would be what I would consider to be one of the show's strongest aspects.  The color palette for this anime is strong, dark, and bold which really compliments and meshes with the scene's background settings creating an overall solemn and dramatic feel throughout the show.  The vivid details put into the death of people in this anime also left my jaw agape with horror at times, but also left me feeling appreciative of the beauty of death basically... and how everything lays out (call me sick but some of the scenes in this anime are powerful...)


The final component of Another is its sound.  The OP for this show is some sort of dark opera song I guess, but it matches the show and does its job.  The ED is a more mellow Jpop tune which gives you relief after an episode filled with tension and horror.  The bgm's do their part of setting the mood for a suspense scene, or horror scene, and it does its job as well and ties in well with the other elements of the show.  In conclusion I had a wonderful time watching this show.  From intricate and detailed story telling, to magnificent gory scenes depicting death and destruction, this show has them all.  The only thing that kept me from rating this a 10 is it's not my usual cup of tea for anime, but nevertheless it's definetly a show worth a watch. :)
