Ever wonder why Horror in general is the least appreciated and the fussiest of all the genres out there? Be it a movie, a TV Series or even a book, Horror has always been an experiment. And not the successful kind of one. You see, horror writers tend to focus on typical "scary" or disturbing elements, use absurd situations as scare tactics, and even rely on previously-used clichés just to be on the safe side. And the worst part is, they try to please every horror fan by mixing everything up together and shattering the story and its characters as a result. Sure, Gore isgreat, even "enjoyable" at some point, but not when it's irrelevant to the plot and used just to induce horror. Because it gets lame really fast. 


“Another” is not one of those exhausting experiments. It's a diversion. It plays the audience as much as the audience "plays" each episode. The first five episodes are creepy to say the least, but not enough to encourage someone to keep watching because story-wise, nothing is actually developed in those episodes. The atmosphere surrounding the characters, their interactions and relationships with one another is just too unsettling and dark. And the viewers have to be patient; it's a price to pay. 


“Another” is an unorthodox show that focuses more on the atmosphere while trying to fool the audience, rather than attempting to scare us using cheap mind tricks. 


This review will consist of two parts: one about the many positives of the show, and the one thing that was in my opinion poorly handled.


(+) POSITIVES


●STORYTELLING: 

MYSTERY: "A cursed and unfortunate class close to Death" is all you can get from 5 episodes. And while this simple phrase seems blurry and lacks any form of context, it makes it easier to tell more than just one story. It’s confusing, but at the same time intriguing, because it creates diversion. Here's the best way that I can describe it: the story is like a chameleon that continuously changes its color skin. In short, the writer meticulously creates a situation with multiple scenarios but showing only one at a time such as convincing the audience that one of the characters is a ghost or a potentially resurrected classmate nicknamed “extra student". The writer chooses to name the female lead character "Misaki" on purpose, which is conveniently the same name as a mysterious person who died 26 years ago and pretty much started all this misfortune. This first part of show succeeds in piquing our curiosity by simply teasing us with mysterious elements before explaining them afterwards. And this is important: it DOES answer the questions it raised contrary to most Mystery animes where they tend to keep you on the edge of your seat but at the end decide to keep all the details for themselves. Of course, raising one or two questions at the end may come in handy in some cases, but not when they only serve as an extra pile of unanswered questions. 


SUPERNATURAL: As expected from a supernatural view, most of the deaths in the show are absurd, especially the first one. But is this excusable? Is it actually linked to the story (or just used for experimentation purposes like excessive gore and violence) ? Since the calamity causes someone related to the cursed classroom to die unexpectedly and sometimes inexplicably, yes. What's the chance of getting killed by an umbrella while walking down the staircase? Close to 0%. But I accept improbable deaths as long as they matter, as long as they are relevant to the core story (In this case, the curse). 


HORROR: Sometimes, the small details matter because they help settle the mood and create something unique. One of the most interesting elements of “Another” is the use of representations to express feelings of loneliess, alienation and emptiness such as the focus on dolls which cleary depict lifelessness and isolation, the interpretations of different paintings (“The Scream”, random sketches of a wingless angel…), the ravens (Death), the rain (indicates misfortune to come and hints at traumas and tears) and the list goes on. The writer even associates the female lead character with complete emptiness by fusing her right eye with one of a doll, as if this wasn’t enough already. Mix those small elements up with a plain and simple horror setting such as “a curse in a school” and you’ll get an interesting result. Because it’s not an ordinary curse anymore, like striking a nail into a straw doll or anything like that. It’s a curse that involves ignorance and disregard (I’m not going to say more than that for fear of spoiling it) which happens to be of the many themes of “Another”. In fact, it shows us the horror by carefully exploring its hidden themes instead of resorting to meaningless violence like most horror shows do.


●ART & ANIMATION: 

I don’t usually take much time in this section, but this time it’s an exception. The art is almost flawless: it’s overly detailed and carefully crafted and drawn to point that you can read the title and cover of the book that one of the background characters is reading, more or less. Speaking of which, every background scene has details and colors instead of the usual “blurry” cartoonish shapes or even worse, the famous “faceless” students in the back. The production team also took their precious time adjusting colors so they can perfectly fit into the scene and setting. They played a bit with wind effects at the beginning, helping us predict that misfortune is about to come, but they got tired of it later on. 


All of the character designs are unique in their own way, making it much easier to distinguish them by their looks instead of their forgettable names. There are no characters that present remotely the same shape, outline and features: they have been drawn with a unique “skeleton” unlike what most animes are doing nowadays, where they focus on one particular design and then keep adding or removing facial features accordingly to match a different character. Apparently, they focused more on Mei Misaki ‘s character design, most likely to further isolate her from the others by adding more dark features than her Manga counterpart (which is cuter and less gloomy).


As for the animation, it’s fluid, concise and delicate. There’s almost no stuttering between frames, or overused jump frames that make question what just happened in the last few seconds. In short, you won’t have to rewind the episode to re-watch a scene, unless you’ve missed the subtitles.   


●CHARACTERS:

Around 20 characters are present, including 5-6 main characters. This makes it impossible to develop all of them in a 12 episode-deadline. Instead, only the main characters are developed, especially Kouichi Sakakibara (Male Lead) and Mei Misaki (Female Lead). The others are only described with a single trait, such as a certain hereditary illness, nothing more. This leads to a certain dilemma: we can have some under-developed characters only if we will kill them later on for the sake of the story. People will complain that those deaths are meaningless as they weren’t invested in those characters and as a result, don’t really care what happens to them. OR: we can try to fully develop most of the characters including their background stories but we will still kill them (the story will remain unchanged). People will be outraged that the writers killed their “favorite” character(s) and wasted their precious time. So what’s the solution here? Well, we can’t have one without the other. And since some characters are cleary more important than others, the stage should be given to them instead. Discard the rest. And this is exactly what “Another” does. It presents its secondary characters by summarizing their traits, nothing more than that, and later on kills them in favor of future events to come. It’s a necessary sacrifice to be made, especially in the horror genre. People die, a lot. And it shouldn’t shock us. It’s a tragedy, and it made it clear from the start. Everyone is on the writer’s Death List, even if you don’t believe it yourself. 


Regarding the characters’ psychological state, it’s messy, crumbled and distorted. They are scared, selfish, even psychotic and violent (last episode) and will do anything to stay alive, even if it meant killing their own classmates. Ironically, the character with the most distinctive traits is the silent one: Mei Misaki. “Another” shows us that there’s another way to express a person’s feelings and state of mind. Words lie (and Mei doesn’t talk much), but representations don’t (the scenes are mostly emphasized on her). The same goes for the main character.


●SOUND:

Most voice actors did a perfect job in conveying the characters’ emotions and feelings, so you won’t find one of those annoying high-pitched voices that makes you wish you were watching a Dubbed version (God Forbids). 


OP made by ALI Project titled “Nightmare Contagion” was awesome and fit the horror-thriller genre perfectly. I recommend you give it a try if you enjoy eerie violin melodies and a good vocalist.


ED was an alright one. 


( - ) NEGATIVES

Besides the slow-paced and dark beginning (first 5 episodes) which will discourage a lot of people to continue, “Another” had one problem. The execution of its last episode. It felt rushed and chaotic, and I believe it was on purpose. The writer wanted to confuse the audience by combining multiple events that happened, or were supposed to happen (some of the events couldn’t be shown on-screen due to time restrictions) while also making many character decisions for no other reason than hype us for the final revelation. Just like us, the characters were confused and lost, but out of their fear of dying miserably by “unfortunate events”, and this backfired a bit. Nonetheless, the ending was on-point and the closure perfectly wrapped up the whole story and may serve as a prologue to a next story with a good ending.


●ENJOYEMENT: I watched “Another” twice as of now. The first time was when it aired and I didn’t quite enjoy it because I didn’t pay much attention to the story and its metaphors. After a second examination, I loved it, maybe because I got tired of the repetitive horror shows out there and wanted something unique in its own way. Not the kind that makes you question your sanity or the writer’s sanity. But the kind that makes you curious, excited, frustrated and even sad at the same time. So to wrap this up:


Give this a try if you:

- Prefer atmosphere and setting over plain and simple horror story 

- Look for acceptable main characters

- Enjoy exploration of dark themes


Avoid this if you are impatient. Otherwise you’ll be disappointed.

If I need to name one caveat I have about this anime, it's this: you can't judge it by its first few episodes. In fact, after watching only the first four episodes, I would have named this one of my least favorite anime of all time without hesitation.
As such, I feel like I  have to divide the show into two parts for the purpose of this review: the "boring-as-watching-paint-dry" part (episodes 1 though 4), and the "interesting" part (episodes 5 through 12). My issue with the first part is simple: almost nothing happens. I know that a slow pace is encouraged and preferable insuspense-driven horror, but there is such a thing as doing too little. Here's some advice to anyone who wants to write, draw, or film anything in the horror or mystery genres: suspense isn't as simple as waiting a long time before doing something scary. You need to keep the audience invested in the meantime. How do you do this? Establish the setting, make the audience invested in the characters by subtly introducing backstory, and (most importantly) give the audience information about the mystery at a moderate pace. Most, if not every, scene should serve a purpose to the plot or the setting. 


I will give this anime credit and say that it does establish the setting very well. By the end of the first episode, I knew who the characters were and what the basic gist of class 3's history was, and I was sufficiently intrigued by the mysterious behavior of all of the characters. The problem is that the next three episodes (and a decent chunk of the first episode, for that matter) do nothing to advance the story beyond that point. Most scenes simply rehash what the audience already knows or consist of nothing more than students giving creepy stares or saying cryptic nonsense to the main character. There are some exceptions, of course, but they are few and far between.  Not only would it be incredibly easy to cut those four episodes down to two episodes without removing any important information, character moments, or suspenseful scenes, but the repetitive nature of these episodes ends up ruining the impressive setting and interesting characters already established. 


By the end of the fourth episode, I thought that every character (excluding the main character's nurse friend) was stupid, annoying or pretentious. This was due in large part to the fact that most of them seemed to be acting creepy or mysterious for no reason other than to act creepy and mysterious, even when outright explaining the situation would serve their own goals far better. The main character, Kouichi Sakakibara, does nothing to alleviate this situation, since he does nothing but stare blankly at the events going on around him. He seems almost unwilling to uncover the mystery behind class 3, frequently letting characters dodge his questions or walk away from him without so much as a word of protest, no matter how blatant it was that they knew more than they were telling. I cannot express how pissed off I was by this sorry excuse for a protagonist. The episodes also try to establish a relationship between him and Mei Misaki, but this attempt is utterly foiled by Misaki's tendency to do nothing other than, you guessed it, give creepy stares and cryptic nonsense.


However, everything changes after episode 4. Without giving too much away, I will say that many of the plot points that the characters have been needlessly holding off on are revealed by the end of episodes 5 and 6, and virtually all the problems that I had with the previous episodes are no longer present. Suddenly the characters begin acting like normal humans; they're friendly with one another, they legitimately try to uncover the mystery, and they develop their own unique, likeable characteristics. Misaki and Sakakibara talk with each other in a believable way. Almost every scene in these later episodes is relevant, even though the pace is still very slow, making the episodes both suspenseful and interesting. 


Take for example episode 8, which is my favorite episode. While I won't give away too many specifics about the plot, I will say that the episode begins with several characters going to a hotel to meet someone who may have a hint regarding the central mystery of the series. During this sequence, they decide to spend the day at the beach while waiting for said person to show up. For most of the episode, there are no new elements of the mystery introduced, nothing bad happens to anyone, and the dark, overcast skies of the rest of the series are abandoned in favor of a sunny beach setting. The characters just spend a day at the beach. Why do I like this episode? Because it has the characters acting like friends. They make jokes, they feud with each other, they have fun. Suddenly the people who I took for one-note, cryptic morons felt like multifaceted, interesting and (most importantly) realistic people. After this episode, I cared about these characters and didn't want anything bad to happen to them. Who cares if the mystery narrative is ground to a halt when the scenes here still serve some purpose to the series? They make the audience develop an emotional connection with the characters that makes the eventual climax of the series far more impactful.


The pace does eventually increase as the series begins to reach its climax, making the last couple episodes feel a bit too fast-paced. However, I do appreciate that the show does still manage to tie up most of its loose ends by the conclusion, and that none of the series' events or twists were predictable or cheap. I do have a few complaints regarding the plot and the overall mystery, but mentioning those would get into spoiler territory.


Overall, I would recommend this series to anyone who wants a decent horror mystery, although there are definitely far better ones out there. I honestly feel like I would have enjoyed it much more if it were shorter or if there was more variety in the first few episodes, but as it stands I give this show a fairly good 6 creepy stares.....out of 10.

Despite its strength in building up mystery and tension, ‘Another’ did suffer from many shortcomings. The pacing issue remained most problematic. I liked the pacing during the first half of the series and I enjoyed the contrast between the slow pacing and the quick surprise deaths. But the ending was obviously too rushed, as if it was unplanned. Many half-baked secondary characters were slaughtered. Each death was all pleasantly gruesome and entertaining but the overall result was a bit messy. Other elements of ‘Another’ were satisfactory. I generally liked the editing of this series. There were several quiet foreboding sequences which I thought was interesting.The music did not stand out as much as I expected but it was okay.

***This is a Spoiler-Free Review***
Before reading this review you may wonder, is Another just [Another] horror anime?  Do I have room for [Another] show to marathon?  Can this reviewer get away with [Another] pun before I slap him? And OH MY is that Chihiro Shindou? (major props for anyone who gets that).  Well worry not my friends this review will answer those questions and more.
Before I proceed any further I must say that after Madoka, I now refer to my former 3-episode rule as "the Madoka rule" in that in order to avoid basic *premise* plot spoilers even if you are thesafest online surfer, one should generally adhere to the watching up to the third episode before reading online commentary, or in some cases, before dropping a show.


Story  [7 / 10] - The roller coaster analogy works well to describe the plot of Another.  The beginning (first two episodes) works very well in setting up the premise just like the initial climb of a roller coaster.  After that, we are left with the aftermath of that first initial *drop*  Erm.  Anyway, the momentum built up to that point seems to be able to carry the show pretty well for the most part.  The viewer is left with a pattern each episode, with something that adds to the mystery and solving it, some character development, and what you might be able to call "fan service"... the "punch" that the viewer is expecting each episode.  Just as one might expect, there are some very creative "train wrecks", like Rube Goldberg machines from hell.  The more chaos that is unleashed, the more our heroes try to find the source of the chaos and stop it.  Wait, wasn't there [Another] anime like this involving cicadas?


Anyway, if you read some of the better written, thoughtful reviews of this show, either on this website or on blogs, you'll find that the only real point of contention is with the ending.  You will either love it or hate it.  If you don't marathon it, and are a weekly watcher like myself, you might share my opinion which was "come on.  Really?  Is that the best you can come up with?"  The roller coaster runs out of steam, and then to make up for it, seems to just hit the accelerator without stopping, or without adherence to the former speed or pacing.  Without spoiling anything, I'll just say that while something akin to the ending was expected, the ending replaced creepy and mood-based mystery/horror with something of a different genre altogether.


[Another] way to describe the ending would be that you could replace the BGM with the Overture from Carmen (youtube it if you don't know what I'm talking about) and it would transform the show from a horror into a pretty effective dark comedy.  It certainly wasn't meant to be funny, but there were parts during the ending where I actually did laugh (one scene in particular involving a light fixture of sorts...)  Once the chaos ends, you're unfortunately left with a fair amount of questions [such as Why Can't My Little Sister Be This Cute? (as Mei)]  Ahem.  Some really don't have answers, or the answer leaves you stuck in a recursive loop.  Maybe the OVA will explain some things, maybe it won't.  It was likely that it was intentional to leave some things untouched.  However, it might have been as simple as the "Elfen Lied flashback"-style fix of adding [another] episode to really make the ending come together.  It's not the unanswered questions that detract from the score, but the way the resolution was handled without really piecing everything together until the last minute.  We're given a few explanations and expected to accept them without question thanks to some hints given both in and out of the show, but parts of the "mystery solving" and flashbacks could have likely taken a full episode than 1/3 of one.


Art & Animation [9/10] - [Another] excellent job by P.A. Works but the credit doesn't just go to them, as there were tons of big name contributors to the Key and In-Between Animation.  Character design and animation are P.A.'s forte of course, but the animation especially in the peak of action is fluid and gorgeous (well as gorgeous as you can find some things to be) and the team is very effectively able to pull off the "creepy" factor as well with not only its characters, but its settings, OP/ED animation, dream sequences... Nothing to complain about here.  And we can be sure that the BD version will remove any doubts that they "held back".


Sound (OST, OP/ED, Voice Acting) [9 / 10] - Would you believe it, [Another] soundtrack composed by the very talented, very multi-faceted Kou Otani.  He is a master of mood tracks, as well as complementing action sequences, and the OST does its job well.  It doesn't have too much replayability outside of watching the anime, but there are some tracks that will clearly remind you of certain scenes when you hear them.


I would just like to say, Animation Studios, I would like to never hear an ALI PROJECT OP/ED ever again.  Please.  Stop it.  A friend seriously commented when he walked into the room and just briefly heard ALI and saw a doll on the TV, "Is that Rozen Maiden"?  There is nothing special about the OP song at al, which is a real shame because the OP animation is wonderful.  The ED on the other hand is a great song, but thanks to the pacing of the show, you might throw something at your screen when the ending pops up.  It's interesting to look at how your perspective on the simple ending animation may change as you watch the show.


Lastly the voice acting.  Well, Abe-san is great of course.  He just fits right into the protagonist role.  Many of the other seiyuu are actually not at all big-name, but Mei's voice actress does a superb job as well, perfectly maintaining her image of mysterious, approachable, and yet socially awkward with a mild dark side.


Character [6 / 10] - [Another] difficult category to rate.  On one hand, the protagonists themselves get a lot of character development.  While there are still aspects of them shrouded in mytery, you get to see the mounting tensions between some of the feature characters, as well as some of the budding relationships between other pairs of characters.  Definitely the main character's relationship with Mei is something to pay close attention to.  Other characters however (including in a couple particular instances, the main characters) function merely as plot devices.  They become disposable and merely a sort of circus act.  That act advances the plot and gives us our daily punchline for sure, but contrasting with a show like Higurashi no Naku Koro ni where stuff actually happens to characters we grow attached to, in Another we don't care as much when something happens to a character we just met that episode, and it becomes more for entertainment purposes than character attachment.  Lastly, especially at the end, some characters remain in character (especially when you imagine their feelings when faced by certain situations) but other characters turn into sort of robots whose programming has gone haywire, and even others are just sort of there for dramatic impact.  Unfortunately that impact isn't as dramatic thanks once again, to the lack of connection we have to those "NPC" type characters.


Enjoyment [8 / 10] - Simply put, it's definitely not [Another] horror anime.  Every episode delivers a satisfying dose of mystery, horror, and train wrecks that one can't help but keep watching.  Even more painful when you have to wait a week for [Another] episode, as this does end up being one of those shows that you have  watch more to see what happens next.  In the realm of entertainment, Another definitely performs, even up to the final episodes which depite being questionable from a plot standpoint, are definitely entertaining in one way or [Another].  


Overall (not an average) [7 / 10]: Another is definitely a ride worth taking.  With its outstanding animation, moody OST, great acting, and interesting premise it is definitely different than some of the other horror anime offerings out there.  However it is not without its flaws, but those are only in certain areas, and are still an area of contention among different viewers.  Definitely watch it as it was one of the better offerings in the Winter season despite everything, but it really doesn't hit the ball out of the park.


I even ended the review without making [Another] joke.  Oh wait.

It's not easy to write a good horror story. Everything in the genre is done to death, and writing up plot elements that haven't been used before can backfire way more times than they can succeed. This is due to the fact that horror is not a genre that can stand very well on its own, and often needs to lean on other genres to be intriguing. Even horror masterpieces like the Shining movie/novel or the Silent Hill 2 video game are reliant on a thorough understanding of psychology and human behavior, as well as being as mysterious as they are horrifying, if not evenmore so.


Human behavior is the key to a successful horror story. A lot of horror stories are heavily reliant on simply giving the characters a back story and being done with it, not hesitating on killing them off afterwards, rather than use the fear as an intsrument to develop the characters are make them, well, more human.


This is where Another comes in. Another is heavily reliant on atmosphere to set up its mystery, and this is where the show shines best. It does a marvelous job at sucking viewers in, making them curious about what happens next and adding more and more plot points and subplots to keep things interesting, especially early on in the show.


This slowly but surely backfires as the show progresses, as it becomes very clear that the writers were simply being atmospheric for the sake of being atmospheric and nothing else. The plot contradicts itself on countless occassions, simply to allow itself to advance and this ruins viewer immersion really quickly.


The deaths that happen over the course of the show are probably the most interesting(read:laughable) aspect of it. The deaths happen in the most random fashion, making us treat the character deaths as nothing more than a joke and forget that they are characters. This makes them nothing more than worthless, since we remember how they died better than how they supposedly lived, meaning that they are flat and one note for the most part.


The story literally feels in retrospect like it could have been solved in the first episode if everyone was simply talking to one another, and this means that the character interactions are easily the most terrible aspect of the show. The characters do not speak to one another like actual human beings, they speak to one another like monotone robots. Actually, scrap that, that's an insult to robots. Robots at least have a reason to be this monotone, unlike the characters in this show.


The artwork and animation quality are this show's saving grace, being extremely fluid and beautiful to look at if not outright gorgeous. The backgrounds look fantastic and the colors fit the mood of the show extremely well, meaning that there is a ridiculous number of great shots and eye candy.


If there is something that I can say, it's that this show entertained me, even if for all the wrong reasons. The story kept me mildly interested until the end and the character deaths were hilarious to watch and had me laughing on the floor at one of them.


Nevertheless, I advise anyone who has experience with other works in the genre to stay away. The mystery is a mess, the characters are bland and there are as many loopholes as a piece of Swiss cheese the size of the pyramids. 


Unless you like stuff like Final Destination or Wrong Turn (ironically or unironically), this show isn't for you.

Once upon a time, there was a girl who could not watch horror movies to save her life. Even as her friends invited her along to watch the Mama movie, which was only rated PG 13, she refused to go because even the trailer scared her. Yes, I'm talking about myself. And trust me, I almost left this anime because I thought it was another one of those horror anime with a lot of blood and killing to satisfy the gory desires of people I did not understand.
If you are like me, a person who does not want to get involved with movies like ParanormalActivity or watch ghosts suddenly appear behind you in a mirror after your shower, STAY! I admit, I almost stopped myself from watching this simply because I was scared that...it might be scary. However, this anime ended up being my favorite (and only) suspense anime so far! Anyway, to the reviews:


Story: 8/10. 

The plot is...intriguing. I promise you that you will simply love every moment, every episode of this scene. There are no unnecessary fillers, no unnecessary moments--every scene is filled with clues and mysteries, keeping you on the edge. 


The overall story is about a boy named Sakakibara and a girl named Misaki. To not give any spoilers, Sakakibara is a new boy at a cursed classroom. If the curse starts, students and their associated families will die every month--and there is no apparent way to stop the curse. Most of the story, you'll feel like Sakakibara, since you know nothing about the mystery. As Sakakibara learns more, you learn more as well, and the mystery unfolds--why only he can see Misaki, for example. 


By the way, have you ever seen an awards show that always did something like, "The first place winner is...(everyone holds their breath)...will be announced after the commercials!" This anime is FILLED with those. They are annoying at times, but these moments truly make the story good. You are forced to wait, even though a crucial clue is just at your fingertips. 


Anyway, the answer to this anime is most unexpected. I dare you to try to guess who it is. And you'll see what I'm referring to when you watch the anime, what the protagonists are trying to find.


I really loved the anime, even though the beginning was a bit confusing as you soak in the information and environment. There's also a tidbit of romance as well, which is highly implicit. I ship Misaki and Sakakibara so hard, I was a little disappointed when their relationship didn't develop further. 


Art: 7/10

Pretty good. There are so gory, bloody scenes in this, but it's mostly not that bad. There are, however, some scenes of random dolls here and there which have little impact on the story...it's kinda annoying. It's as if the anime makers want you to feel scared, but you don't. Because the dolls are kind of cute.


Character: 10/10

You will NOT see much character development. Why? Because you don't even know the characters well enough to begin with. The entire 12 episodes is designed to help you understand the characters--therefore, there's no room for development. However, the characters' relations develop quite significantly, and this makes up the story. When people are dying, what's important is how the relationships between friends change. This is accentuated in the last episode where...well, I'll let you find out.


Enjoyment: 10/10.

As I stated before, I loved this anime. It's filled with A LOT of plot twists and turns, and subtle clues to keep you guessing till the very end. There's plenty of action, and plenty of bittersweet moments as well. Furthermore, if you're like me, you will fall in love with Misaki! She is such an interesting character, who can lead the story by herself (she is also the cutest anime girl I've ever seen, even with her eyepatch).


I hope you try this out! This is not a horror anime, mind you, but a mystery one. If you want to be caught by surprise, or if you are looking for an anime that will keep you on the edge, take this anime up and try it.

Humans are despicable creatures. When all is fine and well, they wear smiles on their faces, going around promoting peace and unity. But when a crisis that threatens them arises, don't expect things to remain the same. Friends suddenly become traitors, acquaintances become enemies, and chaos ensues. The human instinct of "survival of the fittest" kicks in, eliminating the once supported notion of unity. Blood and tears are shed, with no one to clean up the mess. The once peaceful community will become infested with selfish, cruel animals. The difference is like day and night, black and white. This is what Another tries to depict- the horrible, but true, nature of human beings.


Art (8/10)

While the artwork itself is not particularly outstanding or excellent, the way some of the scenes transition from one another makes up for it. Camera angles were used skillfully throughout the series - a close-up shot when wanting to draw attention to something and a wide show when wanting to establish a scene. The sheer amount of symbolism used really required the art to be detailed and captivating, and I felt the animation in Another had no problem with that. Character designs and background elements had a good amount of detail in them; barely anything to complain about. Very solid animation, overall.


Characters (8/10)

To be honest, there really isn't much known about the characters. From start to finish, they are more or less kept a mystery from the audience. Their background, hobbies, family, and any other pieces of personal information are not revealed, with the exception of the two protagonists. While this effectively accentuates the "mystery" aspect of the show, and prevents viewers from analyzing the characters in order to easily solve the mystery themselves, the consequence is the lack of character development for the side characters. This leads to a lower shock value when these characters end up being part of a significant plot event. But in the case of the main characters, Sakakibara Kōichi and Misaki Mei, their characters are developed fairly well throughout the 12 episodes. As the series went on, it was nice to see the two of them slowly open their hearts and grow closer towards each other, and at the same time supporting the other in times of need.


Sound (9/10)

When it comes to horror series, BGM plays a bigger role than usual. If it is unable to set the mood for the scene, the viewer's enjoyment value plummets. Luckily, Another does well in this aspect. The BGM is very noticeable during the suspenseful scenes of the series, enhancing the overall sense of tension in the air. Although there weren't any big name seiyūs involved in this project, I was surprised at how the emotions of the characters were brought out fairly well through their voices. The only setback in this category had to do with the OP. I felt that it wasn't dark enough; it didn't fit the theme of "horror" too well. The slow and soft ED, on the other hand, wrapped up each and every episode magnificently. It's soothing melody is perfect for allowing the viewer to slowly absorb everything that has just been thrown at them.


Story (9/10)

Having often been compared to horror masterpieces like Higurashi no Naku Koro ni and Shiki, it's not like Another has a unique story. But while this may be true, the approach it takes using the plot of "a strange boy in a strange town" is what separates it from the other two. While I do admit to having lost faith in this series during the first half due to the seemingly predictable pattern the story was progressing in, I'm glad I stuck with it to the end. In a way, the slightly disappointing first half helped to lower my expectations for the second half, which ended up being both captivating and shocking. The story as a whole had a good sense of realism to it, making it all the more entertaining.


Overall (9/10)

Another is undoubtedly more psychological than bloody. Each flashback, event or action almost always has a hidden meaning that is crucial to the series as a whole. Because of this, it's re-watch value is very high. I found Another to be one of the best shows of the season; the right elements came together to create a captivating story, full of twists and turns. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a short and interesting psychological thriller.

Another is a 12-episodes-long horror/gore/mystery anime from the Winter season of 2012. It was directed by Tsutomu Mizushima and the two main characters are voiced by Atsushi Abe and Natsumi Takamori.
In the start, a very intense horror atmosphere is created and it hints that this show would be quite scary, but that is destroyed in the third episode when it becomes a full-blown gore. Also, the mystery feels incomplete by the end, the reason for everything that is happening is never fully explained and some aspects are ridiculously convenient, for example: if Mei, one of the protagonists, didn’t have her power, it would be neighimpossible for the class 3-3 to end their situation 


There are some decent stuff. As any mystery, Another has red herrings, quite a lot of them, and they are mostly decently presented. It manages to keep the viewer interested and entertained, despite its problems. The story had a lot of potential, the premise was great, but it all falls flat in the middle and goes downhill because of bad pacing, the lack of discoveries about the reason that all of supernatural stuff happens and the general stupidity of most of the cast.


The characters are by far the worst part of the anime. The only character to receive a bit of development was Mei and most of the other characters are completely bland and forgettable, I can’t remember the name of anyone apart the two protagonists. Also, they are really stupid, in a lot of moments everything would have worked out if they talked to each other and tried to understand what was happening as a group, this is particularly evident in the last two episodes of the anime.


However, there are two things that were really good: the visuals and, strangely, the gore. Another is incredibly pretty, very detailed, the animation is very fluid and the style not only suits the setting, but also goes a great way to create the atmosphere. The gore, in a very twisted way, is enjoyable (I feel really bad and strange about writing this), some morbid part of you actually likes it, as it is nicely presented and has real punch. Sometimes it is ridiculous, but it always is very imaginative and twisted.


Most of the times the soundtrack is brilliantly used to set the atmosphere, but sometimes it is terrible. At one point, I laughed during what should have been a very tense scene because it had a very badly time track that just broke the tension.


Another begins creating an incredible horror and mystery atmosphere, but does nothing with incredible potential and ends up disappointing. But even with all that was bad, I greatly enjoyed watching it and felt intrigued by its premise (this is what made me continue watching it).


If you are looking for a series with very good gore or just eye-candy, watch it. Don’t watch it expecting great characters, a masterfully executed story, good supernatural elements or a satisfying mystery.

Another!
It's Another horror anime! 
Those who watch this show will usually be split into three camps! The first camp claims that this show is great since it has an amazing atmosphere. The art, the soundtrack, and the animation, all of it just screams SPOOKYYYY!!! 
The second camp shakes its head, calls the first camp a filthy casual, and claims that this show is a shitty horror story! They claim that there is no logic whatsoever in the mystery, and that the characters act incredibly stupidly, as if they are simply letting themselves be killed without making any progress in solving the mystery. 
The third campsimply bitch slaps both of them and claims that Another is quite possibly the most hilarious show ever to grace the medium. After all, some of these death scenes are just completely outrageous. Sometimes I don't know if these scenes are supposed to be taken seriously or as a joke, and the third camp takes it as the latter. 


So which camp is correct? Well, I'll be that guy and say that they are all correct! Another is a highly atmospheric well executed illogical piece of comedy. 


When I watched this show for the first time, I was scared shitless! I've always been scared of horror movies, and even though horror anime aren't really scary, I was still unable to sleep. Upon finishing it, I was soooo proud of myself! I thought I had just gone through the best horror anime ever created!


But now, since the Another death scenes are in almost every Anime vines or Anime crack video, I don't even know if Another should be considered a horror anymore. Yes, the scenes are really brutal, but when you take it into context... it's outrageous. Why did this character die like that? What the hell?


Another is simply a show to watch for the brutality. The mystery may be interesting, but the way it tries to solve the mystery leaves much to be desired. The story may be thrilling, but when you think about it, it's also pretty stupid. The characters are... ok? Mei gives off a very mysterious vibe, but over time, she just becomes a Kuudere version of Rikka. The MC is pretty unique in the sole fact that he actually wants to solve the mystery, but really, he just wants to. He doesn't really even try.


If you want a thriller mystery with actual substance, Higurashi is still your best bet! The deaths actually have meaning and contribute to the story, and it's even got more comedy than Another. 


TL;DR: Final Destination is my favorite Smash bros stage.

Another is a satisfyingly bloody little cup of anime. There is a haunting atmosphere, a refreshing plot resolution and kids dying gruesome, gory deaths. What more do you want?
Story: Clueless transfer student lands smack in the middle of a cursed classroom where the unlucky students and their family are dying in horrifically inventive ways. And you thought your failing math test scores were the worst thing that could happen… 
Now, the story has some very good points and some not so good points. It gets cookies made of sparkly awesomeness for producing twists that keep up the interest, letting the characters do stuff that isunexpected, pulling the rug from beneath the viewer’s feet in sudden delight and generally keeping up a creepilicious atmosphere throughout the whole.  It never reaches top score due to the fact that in order to have these plot twists make sense it sometimes needs to give real flimsy excuses, aka pulling shit out if its ass. Not that it detracts much, in a show like this, it’s the body count that matters and this anime delivers gore in bucketfuls. 


Characters: 

Sakakibara the transfer student is the main character we follow for the majority of screentime but it is essentially the whole cursed class interacting together that makes the show shine. Alone, Sakakibara is just your everyday joe but since every other character adds a little something to every action and conversation they have together it snowballs into giving everybody depth. Now, since this is a “whodunit” show I won’t analyse the characters because much of their evolution hinges on spoilers. Wait for it, they are very fun to be around. 


Animation:

This show is straight up scenery porn, the backgrounds are simply jaw-dropping. Everything looks sleek and clean and motions are fluid. There are a couple of weird frames here and there but keep those eyes on the porn—the scenery porn that is, don’t go thinking dirty thoughts now. 

About the only nitpicky complaint I have is the character design. Why the frak do they all look 5 years old, even 30 year old adults included? A more realistic design would have lifted this up to a perfect score. 


Music:

The music really sets the tone here. It is creepy and spooky and perfectly keyed to crucial moments. It knows when to play and when to stop. Me gusta. 

OP: A lot of dismembered dolls and deliciously creepy scenes set to a gothicky jpop tune.

ED: boring ballad and a still picture that just screams red—pun intended—herring. 


Overview:

This was immensely enjoyable and quite gory. Starts slow, builds up carefully and just explodes in the end. Recommended for all who liked the Ring.

That was when the first person was systematically murdered for some reason, and then I find out there is some kind of "Force" behind the fact that there are a certain number of people in the class, as opposed to another.... What? that is just confusing as hell, and whats worse, the girl with the eye patch apparently is that "extra student", for some reason, and the main character talks to her, and then he gets ostracized by the rest of the class.... I don't know. I wasn't able to follow the story. The real "extra" person you find out is actually a bit of a surprise, but also isn't, if you really think about it. (Yes, I will tell that much: The real "extra" person is technically not her)


The art was probably the best aspect of this, and even that isn't that great. For a more modern anime, it certainly isn't the best, but some of the explosions and other things like that did look more realistic at times. The blood and gore were okay looking, but they didn't leave an impression. Basically, when someone died, I am not surprised at how much blood and gore are there, but with actually how they died being. There was only one death that actually looked pretty cool, while also being disturbing, and it actually isn't one of the students. (Not much of a spoiler, but still one I guess.) 


The sound wasn't really much of a spectacle. I wasn't impressed by it. The opening song, closing song, etc. It just didn't give that much of an impression, nor was it horrible.


The characters are, by far, the worst aspect to it. You mostly get the different tropes that are within a typical school setting, for the most part, and there is not much more exploration into the anime about it, but it did have a couple characters that stood out. The class representative (Red-haired chick. Dont remember her name) and the main character, but even then, they were just not that interesting. Until the first death, there really wasn't much bad with the characters.


Overall, I kinda enjoyed this anime, but at the same time, I had to realize that it really wasn't good and decent is the best I can really give it. Its an anime to see, just to see, not really anything more. Kinda spooky at times though.

Another is an anime with a LOT going for it. We open the show through a young man named Sakakibara, who has moved in with his grandparents/aunt now that his father (an archeologist) is out of Japan. This means that Sakakibara has to transfer to Yomi Yama North, the local high school, and while there he meets a mysterious young woman with an eye patch. One that the rest of the class doesn't seem to know exists.
It's hard to go into the plot without fear of spoilers, so I'm going to have to be as vague as the show was - and that KILLED me.The show is a mystery-one, where as the viewer (and the characters) solve one problem, there's another, greater problem lying just beneath it. The problem with this is that it takes FOREVER for them to start. Approximately four episodes are spent solving the mystery of eye patch girl (Misaki Mei) and having the extended cast dodge the question. Whenever Sakakibara asks a question, the other students just look around nervously and give some vague reason as to why they can't answer. AND HE LETS IT GO. Where's the drive? Where's the need to solve this mystery? Why is Sakakibara so passive about this? You might be seeing a ghost or something and you're just gonna let it pass by? What the hell is that?


Other than the shows "taking forever to get to the point"edness, Another is an intriguing, entertaining anime. The main thing pushing the show is the mystery and the atmosphere - and boy, Another has some GREAT atmosphere. The surrounding environments are realistic, yet bleak - even a stereotypical beach episode isn't light and bright and airy. The sky is grey, there are no bird calls, and the beach is abandoned, save for our cast. It really hits home the feeling of dread that fills the students, as well as the tension.


My only other gripe is some of the detailing in the final episode, but that's not enough to deter from this show. If you're looking for a good mystery and don't mind some blood (i.e. tons of blood), then Another is a solid show. Nothing that special, but solid.

I started watching this show thinking of it as a mystery, and was instantly hooked by the ominous, foreboding atmosphere which made me question what exactly was going on (in a good way). The first few episodes did an amazing job of introducing the cast and presenting several bizarre and unsettling elements in a way that reminded me of Twin Peaks.
I had really high expectations after experiencing such an interesting first part, but then Another did something I feel supernatural mystery/horror series should never do, and chose to answer most of the bizarre mysteries that got me hooked on the show in the first place,failing to present any new ones after that. Then it paved the way to becoming something akin to Final Destination, where all that was left was watching lots of bizarre deaths with little to no real mysteries or uncertainties involved. That seriously hampered my enjoyment of the series, as I felt like they had really nailed the ominous and paranoid atmosphere at first.\n\n
Judging the series as a whole, I'd say it's good if you want to watch some horror, but not so much if you want to be scared by supernatural or unknown things rather than grisly death scenes and nothing else.

Back in 2011, I was looking to the upcoming 2012 anime seasons...and to be honest, it looked bleak...but there was one gem that caught my attention and that was Another. There's a pretty good reason though, Mystery Anime + Horror/Slasher + P.A. Works (Producer of Angel Beats, my personal favorite anime) = MUST WATCH!
So, I did, and I must say, it lived up to the expectations. 
Positives
There are a lot of positive things I can say about this anime. What I loved most about it was the dramatic suspense the writers created with the situations and scenarios they placed the characters into. I felt genuinelyafraid for each character because it felt like any one of them could die at any moment. The character building between the two leads (Sakakibara and Misaki) was really well done. While I'm sure some would call Sakakibara a fairly dull character, he felt extremely relateable to me. He was a character that for the most part, was able to keep his calm under pressure...and I think his prior situations revolving around death had a lot to do with his personality. I also have to say the twists that this anime created were absolutely fantastic. I really could not see many of them coming even though I did semi-predict early on in the series what needs to happen to end the curse. Even the situations early on in the anime had me guessing and for the most part, guessing wrong. Even the final twist in this anime I never saw coming and I loved how this anime explained the subtle hints that were there all along but brushed them off because they didn't feel important. The music in this anime was absolutely fantastic and matched the tone of the anime perfectly. In fact, I thought the WORST song of this anime was actually the opening. The ending credits in my opinion, was one of the best I've ever seen. The imagery, the music, everything about the ending was just gorgeous. Perhaps the best dynamic of this anime was how it portrayed death. Trust me, this wasn't an anime where character falls over and slowly slumbers into death. This anime is gory, its graphic, and there is nothing beautiful or heartwarming about how the characters die. Blood curdling gasps of final breaths, muscle spasms of those passing into death, it all felt extremely realistic. The producers of this anime had a strong grasp of what happens when someone goes through a violent, painful death. To top it all off, I believe this anime had a very satisfying ending as well. It wasn't too happy, it wasn't too sad, they did enough to conclude this anime completely and left enough open where they could expand upon the story. Although, that does lead me to my negatives...\n\n
Negatives\n
While I did believe the story for Another was really good, they left a few things untouched. For example, why this "curse" even exists in this town. Now, approximately halfway through this anime, a character (I can't remember who) did explain that this curse "was natural in Yomiyama. It's much like how typhoons and earthquakes are natural anywhere else." I didn't really buy that. As the viewer, we know sort of how this curse came along with the student 24 years prior dying suddenly and the class pretending that that student was still alive. However, it didn't really explain as to why that class is cursed, why this event takes place, how it even came to be. Or what causes the dead to come back to life and manipulate the memories of those around them. If there was some backstory about how someone cursed the town, the school, the class, whatever, I might buy it. However, we had nothing. Just the "natural" causes. I really don't care who you are, that's not natural, I'm sorry, its not. Another negative about this anime in my opinion was the character building between Sakakibara and his classmates. It was difficult to get emotionally invested in a lot of the classmates. One classmate does die early on and I think the creators were supposed to make us feel like we should be invested in that character, I had a hard time doing it. I had a hard time getting invested in Akazawa and she's probably the 3rd most important character in this whole anime. Toward the end of the series, I started to understand it a bit and feel for her character, but for the most part, she just felt like another pawn in this series. I do believe the short length of this anime had something to do with that...but hey, Angel Beats was short and I was still able to get invested in the characters of that anime. \n\n
Overall\n
While I did elaborate a bit more on the negatives, don't take them too seriously. This series is great in every aspect. I'm not a big horror/slasher fan but I do enjoy a good, paranormal mystery by one of my favorite anime studios out there. I guarantee you that this anime will have you making wrong guess after wrong guess as to what is going to happen next. I had a very hard time seeing what was going to happen or who was going to die next. Nevertheless, I've never enjoyed being wrong so many times moreso than I did watching this anime. Even if you are not a fan of this genre, it still might be worth the watch.

Normally I'm a stranger to the horror genre in anime, with the only other titles I've seen being Elfen Lied and some of Higurashi. Therefore, I came into Another with only a faint idea of what the series was about and what to expect. What I got was a pleasant surprise that rekindled my interest in the genre and provided me with one of the most suspenseful shows I've seen to date.
Story - 8.5
If nothing else, Another is an example of suspense done right. Despite being classified as a horror anime, Another is more along the lines of a suspense/thriller with strong horror overtones. Theseries does a good job of keeping a lingering sense of unease most of the time, and I guarantee there will be a few shivers that creep down your spine before it ends. But the suspense is not the only thing Another has to offer; its story is engaging, mysterious and kept me interested from episode one all the way to twelve, so much so that I found myself constantly wanting to push the 'next episode' button in order to decipher the mystery behind Class 3.


The beginning does a good job of setting the mood and establishing exposition by feeding you information in little pieces, as well as making known the fear felt by everyone over the horrific happenings in the school. One particular thing I liked was how the character deaths were done; the series has no problem killing off anyone it so chooses, and I loved the nail-biting feeling that nobody is safe from the nightmare. The story does slow down a bit towards the middle, almost feeling like a dark slice of life show in some sequences, but what the middle lacks in pace, the end more than makes up for. The final few episodes do not disappoint, and the climax and conclusion were dramatic and exciting to watch. To put it simply, you'll definitely walk away from Another with a satisfied smile.


Characters - 4.5


Despite the very well-done story, the characters of Another are weak to say the least. Most remain static throughout the series and have no real development or purpose to speak of, other than to be killed off as fodder. Moreover, the characters' emotions (mostly) did not seem fitting of a horror show, as people rarely panic despite the gruesome scenes that unfold. Nowhere is this more evident than in our two main characters. Sakakibara seems more like a plotline device than a horror protagonist, as most of the time his only role is for the audience to simply witness events through his eyes. Misaki fares no better in her evaluation, showing even less emotion than Rei from Evangelion, though her character does develop a bit towards the end of the series. Save for a couple of stand-outs from the supporting cast, the rest of the characters are forgettable and don't do much for the story.


Animation/Art - 9.0


The visuals of Another are undoubtedly the high point of the show. Despite the gruesome content, there are plenty of beautiful backdrops and settings present in this anime, and I was awestruck with some of the detail that P.A. Works put into the art. The animation is fluid and doesn't feel choppy at any point, and it particularly shines through in the gory death scenes. The lighting is done brilliantly, adding even more to the suspense and creepiness felt in the darker parts of the show. There's scarcely something not pleasing to the eyes in Another, making it a real treat to watch.


Sound - 7.0


To put it bluntly, the opening for Another is terrible, feeling more like a demented Adams Family tune than the intro for a horror anime. The ending follows suit, being completely forgettable and not fitting the series well at all.

But despite these hiccups, the rest of Another's score is well-done. Though no pieces stand out as defining works, the music does a good job of setting the tone for each scene. One thing I also appreciated was that the series was not afraid to use silence in order to make the viewer shift in their seat, adding to the already-tense atmosphere created by the story. The dub was solid, enough to leave me satisfied and not feel obligated to watch the entire sub, but there were no stand-out performances other than Jessica Boone, who did an excellent job voicing Akazawa.


Personal Enjoyment - 9.0


Another kept me on the edge of my seat all the way through until the end. Though the characters hold the show back from being truly amazing, it is still an enjoyable anime that I recommend to anyone who enjoys suspense and a good story.


Final Score - 7.6

Mild spoilers ensue:
Well, it wasn't bad...a lot of the time, I actually found it to be quite interesting. I think the plot just tried to overdo itself. Personally, I would have loved for it to have had more to do with the dolls...they were a creepy, albeit, pointless add on. For a horror show, it wasn't scary, though it did have a few cool death scenes and some gore which was helpful. The ending when chaos started to ensue was also pretty cool. I just didn't like the fact that Mikami Mei knew the whole time and just decided not to tell anyone. It's like...why?Was it just to drag the story out? Its an ignorant "horror movie" tactic and it hardly ever works. This show seemed to borrow a whole bunch of other movie plots (i.e. The Sixth Sense, Final Destination, Every cursed high school movie etc) and try to evolve them into something more...it felt like too many ideas rolled into one. The overall reveal was kinda cool and unexpected, but the fumbling way we got there was the problem.


I know most of my review has been focused on what I didn't like, but what I did like were some of the earlier episodes. Though this show started slow, the atmosphere was creepy and the whodunit plot line had me hooked early on, so it wasn't all bad. I loved Akizawa she was badass, but most of the other characters including the protagonist were stock...also they never explained all these heart problems and lung problems the characters had...was it just to move the plot along? 


Overall, it was cool. The "Final Destination" style deaths were interesting and some of the reveals (Including the big reveal) were pretty awesome...but the story got muddled along the way so when these reveals did come, they didn't have the shock value OMG I wanted, and they felt contrived a bit. Also useless sub plots (I.e. the dolls and Sakikabara's dad, the mom's death etc) were useless and unexplained. The deaths from 26 years prior to now that were ONLY explained and not shown were confusing most of the time since they tended to be car accidents or falling. The music was good, but some of the voice acting was sub par. 


Verdict - Above average, but barely. 5.5/10.
